review__text: The article addresses a contingent and very relevant problem, and includes both a national diagnosis of the use of good practices and a solution (concrete good practices). - The language is appropriate. - The article feels like the concatenation of three different articles: (1) survey results, (2) good security practices, (3) incorporation of good practices. - The order of the sections would be better if it reflected this order (the revised version is #2, #1, #3). - The article has no validation of any kind, not even by expert evaluation.

The article presents practical recommendations for developing secure software. Recommended best practices for developing software that is proactive against attacks are described, and a cost analysis of these practices in software development is performed. All based on a review of practices proposed in the bibliography and their contrast with data obtained from a company survey. Finally, a guide is recommended. It would be ideal to apply the proposed guide to companies not involved in the survey that originated it in order to be able to evaluate its effectiveness independently.

The topic is very interesting and a guide to incorporate security practices can be very helpful. - The presentation (description, stage and use) of the 9 practices for the development of secure software. - The “real state of software development in Chile” (as indicated in his paper) cannot be achieved with only 22 surveys out of a total of 50. - It presents nine tables that correspond to the practices for the development of secure software, but the guide presents 10 practices. explain why? - I suggest improving the guide, the greatest contribution is in the incorporation sequence it proposes. Furthermore, she should not explain the practice in Observations or differentiate it from other practices in that column, but rather should give suggestions on how to apply it. - In the text it indicates “Later, three extra practices are also presented…” What are they or did I not read correctly? - According to the format, put at least 5 keywords. - I suggest mentioning the practices before showing each table. - Some references are incomplete, for example, missing year in reference 17, missing year and type of event in reference 11, missing publisher in reference 19 (is it a book?) - Some titles have a comma inside the quotes, for example, reference 1

An experience of using ICT for academic collaboration is explained in an orderly and didactic manner. The originality of the work is not its strong dimension, see long-standing works such as Gorton et al. (1997) and current ones such as Lanunile et al. (2010). However, the relevance of the topic as a reference standard in activities related to scientific theses, associated with its good presentation, make it a contribution. It is suggested, with a view to a magazine publication, that the efficiency and effectiveness of the activities without the support of these tools be compared versus the current reality (with tools). Examples of possible questions to answer from this exploratory analysis: What are the main activities where the use of collaborative tools is key? What changes in the design of these tools should be developed in the future? Are there student/academic profiles more conducive to the adoption of these platforms? References: Gorton, I., Hawryszkiewycz, I., and Ragoonaden, K. 1997. Collaborative tools and processes to support software engineering shift work. BT Technology Journal 15, 3 (Jul. 1997), 189-198. Filippo Lanubile, Christof Ebert, Rafael Prikladnicki, Aurora Vizcaíno, "Collaboration Tools for Global Software Engineering," IEEE Software, vol. 27, no. 2, pp. 52-55, Mar./Apr. 2010.

The authors describe a methodology to collaboratively develop theses and reports using technologies that are commonly used in software development. Likewise, they describe specific tools and their benefits, such as, for example, Latex and Git. Finally, they propose a workflow for the development of projects of this nature. The main value of the article lies in the application of knowledge that students already master - that is, software development techniques and tools - to a different problem such as the theses and reports. All of this, with the aim of making the process more efficient. 1.- The emphasis of the article is on the solution without making a detailed analysis of the problem that is intended to be solved. In other words, there are no answers to the following questions: a.- What exactly is the problem? b.- What impacts does this problem generate? c.- Why is it important to solve the problem? d.- What solutions have been implemented to date? e.- What advantages does the proposed solution have compared to the previous ones? 2.- In my opinion, the article should emphasize the methodology and workflow more. For example, adding a diagram -using visual language- that allows, on the one hand, to understand the general process of thesis development and, on the other, to distinguish the roles, activities and technologies associated in each phase of the report. 3.- Some aspects of the language and the rigor of certain statements must be taken care of, such as, for example: "(given the rather atrocious spelling that engineers enjoy)". Do the authors have any empirical support to support this claim? Is it necessary to resort to such prosaic language to justify the convenience of using a certain technological tool? By the way, I recommend reviewing the expressions: "it is not public" (point 3.1) and "Having direct access..." (point 3.2)

This work proposes a new approach based on [25] to support the recommendation of RSs by evolving the weights of user features through two approaches of using genetic algorithms. The work seems technically correct and the proposal presents robust results according to what is presented in the document. The document has a series of apparently typographical errors that lead to confusion, where the names of variables, abbreviations or presentation format of subscript variables, etc. are changed. For example: equation 2, function w, abbreviation CF, figure 3, figure 6. The approach apparently uses only a part of the DB for efficiency reasons, it would be good to use some indexing technique to support this process.

This paper aims to show new implementation alternative for recommender systems. To this end, the authors use two variations CHC genetic algorithm. -It's a good job. -It is clear and very detailed. - There are inconsistencies in the notation should be improved. The formula (7) has a notation different from the rest of the equations. - On the same point, the figure (3) refers to "profile", "pesos", "euclidean" and "vecindad"; these words aren't related with the text. - I think that the results shown in graphs would be more useful if they are shown in tables.

The paper is well structured. It follows a logical sequence of sections. The paper does not fix to the Infonor conference template. The english grammar is poor. It makes the paper difficult to read and follow. Either: a) rewrite the paper in Spanish, or b) make the paper reviewed by a professional translator Most of the references are not recent (2005-2010). No new work since 2003? Some references do not indicate year. Problems with equations, fonts, etc. Figures 5-17 are not referenced/discussed/explained. It may be better to present these figures as a table. Both, result analysis and conclusions, declare that GA CHC is better than Pearson's correlation Algorithm. However, this analysis and conclusion is not supported for a wide variety of situations and conditions. Therefore, a true validation work is missing.
Novel quantum encryption modeling work is being carried out. I don't see any negative aspects.

This paper involves the development of an application that simulates the BB84 protocol, an orderly work can be seen and without a doubt the understanding of some concepts of quantum physics that support quantum cryptography such as the non-cloning theorem and the principle of superposition and Interweaving is a task that has its merits. In addition, the use of software engineering is appreciated in the construction of the application, which is a very positive aspect, since generally when software creation is involved in frontier areas of knowledge, it is resorts to code-and-fix, with all the disadvantages that this entails. I believe that this manuscript should be directed to the area of ​​cryptography and security. In my specialty, which is computing in distributed environments, I do not see significant relevance and contribution of the manuscript. Using RMI, in my opinion, is not a contribution per se, since RMI is easy. to use if JAVA is used, however, it is not interoperable since it does not support other programming languages. In addition, RMI-based systems have a performance problem as they grow; The more they grow, the slower they become. On the other hand, According to some purists a client/server system is not a distributed system, according to others the client/server case is the most basic case of distributed computing, in short, speaking strictly from the area of ​​​​distributed computing I do not see relevance in this area of ​​this manuscript, however, it seems to me that in another area the paper could be relevant, since it is an orderly, clear and well-written work. I am not an expert in the area of ​​cryptography, but a few years ago I once heard an Englishman in a seminar talk about quantum cryptography and he mentioned a large number of simulators and applications, he even said he had applications that already used quantum cryptography among several. kilometers by means of optical fiber, then I think it is best to evaluate this manuscript in that area and not in the grid/distributed systems area, since in this area the paper in my opinion does not have original aspects, since it uses trivial aspects of the client/server principles. As I have said before, the paper has more issues of quantum physics and cryptography than of distributed computing, so abstracting from the area that concerns me, I see the use of a distributed environment technology used as a client/server, not interoperable and with scalability restrictions. A positive aspect of the paper is that the use of software engineering is appreciated. Regarding the area of ​​​​grid computing and distributed systems, the manuscript does not contain relevant aspects, it uses RMI to implement a client/server system, however, RMI is easy to use and as a good known paradigm in computing, performance is contrasted with ease of use, RMI does not escape that, because it is easy to use, but it does not have scalability. The document is well presented, perhaps table 2 and table 3 would be better to merge them using rows as computer and in the columns the details of the network, especially if more than a client/server scheme there is, for example, a network distribution ring. quantum keys, with more than 2 computers involved. I think that presented to the area of ​​cryptography and security would be more relevant.

Innovative proposal. Well structured. Correctly written. I only suggest: Explain the trapezoidal function on page 2 in more detail. Rewrite the previous paragraph to the trapezoidal function A(x). Enlarge the diagram in figure 1. Explain the proposed architecture shown in figure 2. Review reference by Feng et al. which is reference 2 and in a paragraph of column 2 page 1 is marked as reference 1. Article is not in the format requested by Infonor, please change to this format.

The topic is interesting and is well structured in terms of the design of the proposal. The topic deals with an approach for improvement, however it only establishes an architectural proposal, focusing on the design, and does not indicate how this improvement will be evaluated or measured for the SDWs, it is recommended to add metrics or other aspects for this. It does not provide many details, it is recommended to increase the number. of pages to improve this aspect. There are not many bibliographical references to related works or efforts on the topic.
With a high technical profile, it is a contribution to the topic. Too concise, it could be expanded on how (especially from the fuzzy contribution).

- Innovative proposal for the application of an industrial engineering methodology to the field of requirements engineering. - There is no unification of terms throughout the document, related to the requirements engineering phase: 'eduction', 'elicitation'... The same term must always be used. - It is not evident how the gradual 'improvements' of the eduction process are quantified, and the 'improvement' in the quality of the documentation... how do they measure this improvement? - There are writing and spelling errors, particularly in the use of accent (tildes) and punctuation marks (use of commas and semicolons). The article proposes the use of a work philosophy from another area of engineering, to improve the quality levels of the requirements documents generated in a requirements elicitation process. I consider that from a technical point of view it would be important to support the analysis of results that they propose in a quantified measurement or comparison, which allows, through a more formal method than the descriptive one, to generate conclusions of 'improvement' in the quality of the products. associated with the requirements engineering process. It is not evident how they reach the conclusions generated, what are they based on to say that it is better or not, that it has fewer errors or not? It is an interesting proposal that can be applied in real cases of requirements engineering processes. Currently it contributes to reducing the crisis associated with this phase of software product development. The organization of the document can be improved considerably. I consider that they dedicate a large part of the article to expressing the associated conceptual framework, and less to the application of the technique in the case study and the analysis of results, sections in which the proposal presented can be further supported. Likewise, there are spelling and writing errors that, if avoided, can give greater value to the presentation of the article.

Try to apply a new strategy to requirements management. The applicability of techniques from manufacturing processes to software processes is not supported or considered. While it is true that there are authors such as Demming who propose that it is possible to do so, there are other authors such as Sommerville who propose that due to the characteristics of software development, manufacturing process techniques are not applicable to software. The authors of this article do not provide support regarding the validity of this aspect. The article begins by stating that the proposal is to improve the generation of requirements, however, it then follows that what is improved is the generation of the SRS. The eduction and generation of the requirements document are different aspects. In the case of experimentation that is presented, it is nowhere to be seen that problems are solved either in the eduction or in the generation of the SRS, they are rather implementation problems. The errors detected are basic aspects that any programmer with a minimum of experience knows how to solve, without the need for the SRS to specify the type of minimum validations that must be carried out as part of the system tests. The proposal lacks practical guides to help in its application. How should these POKA-YOKE reviews be carried out? What aspects should you pay attention to? Are there artifacts to guide the review? There are editing errors in the text (repeated words) There are spelling problems (word accentuation)

Good practice to guarantee quality in requirements elicitation - The summary is poorly written, there should be no theoretical explanations - The translation of the summary is terrible - The article is not written in the third person - The POKA YOKE Section should come before the VARIABILITY section OF THE REQUIREMENTS AND COST OF QUALITY. - There are several spelling errors

The article details a requirements management proposal based on KAIZEN. The authors describe different methods and techniques to complement Kaizen. I understand that the main contribution of this work is, according to the authors, to complement and improve Kaizen for requirements elicitation and management. However, the authors of the article present only a theoretical construction of their proposal. I understand that the article needs work to be developed, in order to validate the proposal. However, since it is an article developed by six researchers, I consider that it should include more application aspects of the proposal.
Interesante trabajo.  si bien el documento muestra una propuesta, sería interesante mostrar aplicaciones.

The paper describes an experience concerning the automated inspection of spectra for the Pipeline Hubble Legacy Archive Grism data.  Comments:  In the conclusions the authors say that "We have identified two classes of flawed spectra which were not picked up by the automatic classification because of their very small number of training samples. Per construction machine learning techniques can not classify such outliers." This sentence should be further explained. As Hastie, Tibshirani, and Friedman say in The Elements of Statistical Learning (see Chapter 7): "it is too difficult to give a general rule on how much training data is enough; among other things, this depends on the signal-to-noise ratio of the underlying function, and the complexity of the models being fit to the data. " So, by just saying that the number of training samples is small you do not provide enough information to decide whether machine learning techniques are adequate or not to solve a problem.  Other minor comments:  + If reference [2] has not yet been written or published it should be deleted from the paper.  The dataset may be of scientific importance.  It is mainly descriptive.

This manuscript addresses an interesting solution based in machine learning techniques to classify spectra legacy data of the Hubble Space Telescope in order to publish the results and "good" spectra in Internet to scientific community. The manuscript is well-written and results are robust. Experiment is sound and the manuscript seems acceptable in the current form. The work can be short, but very interesting to the Infonor and JCC community.  The main problem of the paper is that it is difficult to compare results for the classifiers utilized. A confusion matrix and parameters for each classifier could clarify results.

Interesting application domain.  Nothing new from a machine learning perspective. They authors should provide more information about the models they have obtained with the different classifiers (feature subset selection used, selected features, accuracies, statistical significance on the differences on accuracies, the models themselves, ...). Semi-supervised classification is the appropriate method for the last paragraph in the "Methodology" section.

This paper presents a tool (SAVE) for software architecture verification. SAVE performs a static check of rules associated with permitted and prohibited dependencies between design and code elements, and allows a report to be delivered on the consistency between both levels with respect to said rules. Overall the tool seems quite powerful for two reasons: the use of simple rules and the inclusion of pre-defined rule sets for widely used design patterns. This, in my opinion, is the most important difference with other similar frameworks. The writing is, in some places, not very objective. In particular, I would suggest avoiding excessive use of adjectives for which no supporting evidence is provided. For example, in several places I noticed the use of "powerful tool", "intuitive tool" or similar (not only referring to SAVE, but to other works). In all these cases, evidence is not explicitly provided to support the use of said adjectives. Another detail that requires fixing is the title that appears in the PDF file: "Prediction of behavioral dynamics...", which does not match the title of the paper. The authors probably used a template from a previous paper with that title.

Verifying the architecture of a software product can be a great contribution to its quality, therefore, any tool that facilitates this task is a contribution to software engineering. They present evidence of a prior review of alternative or complementary methods and tools to the proposal. The descriptions presented are accompanied by explanatory examples. The role and interaction of the domain expert is not clear. In the initial sections it says that the tool performs static and dynamic analysis, however at the end of the article, in the identification of possible improvements to SAVE it is proposed to include dynamic analysis, which contradicts the initial statement. The description of the tool's operation is not clear enough. The quality of the figures is not adequate, due to their size and resolution it is not possible to appreciate the details well. The article writing can be improved. There are several sentences where connectors are missing, for example "In this section, we will see S.A.V.E. manages to recover the existing dependencies in the source code...." Many errors in the accentuation of the words.

Novedosa propuesta, muy valorable la vinculación de personas del ámbito empresarial lo que permite que la teoría y propuestas para ingeniería de software puedan ser probadas en ambientes reales. Bien estructurado y muy bien redactado.  Solo sugiero esquematizar las actividadesde aplicación de entrenamiento White Belt IR - SixSigma y revisar pequeños detalles de redacción.
Buena práctica para mejor la calidad en la ingeniería de requisitos  - En el resumen no debería haber teoría - Debería haber un caso de estudio para ver mejor la aplicación de la metodología

Interesante propuesta en un ambiente de desarrollo de software que es bastante pobre en aspectos metodológicos de desarrollo.  Falta un poco de trabajo relacionado o quizás discutirlo mejor en la introducción con referencias para fundamentar la interesante propuesta. Revisar redacción. No está en formato pedido por Infonor. Se sugiere no agregar links de páginas web en el texto del artículo.

The authors have designed a methodology to develop software to support scientific research projects. They identify quite precisely the differences between the development of research software and software for commercial purposes. Likewise, they propose a methodology following an approach of agile software development methods. The proposal is in a design phase, has been developed based on interviews with potential users and is susceptible to being tested in future research. In my opinion, the article lacks a section that explains the methodology that the authors followed to arrive at the proposal. Reference is made to interviews with: "participants in this type of projects", however, it is not reported how many people were consulted, how the interviewees were selected, what instruments were applied and how the data were analyzed.

Considero, antes que nada, que el ámbito de desarrollo de la temática (desarrollo de software en ambientes de investigación...) no "otorga permiso" para realizar este desarrollo en forma más informal (tiempos, relajos en versiones, escasa documentación, etc.). 2º, no veo porque se plantea sólo SCRUM, sin hacer comparaciones básicas con los otros exponentes "clásicos" de metodologías ágiles (XP y FDD), lo cual le otorga una cierta "liviandad" al análisis inicial de parte de los autores (sin duda se podría ahondar un poco más, sobretodo con XP).

It is an article that presents a novel topic in the area of Software Engineering. The article is very well documented and substantiated. The technologies used in the development of the prototype are of current interest. As the article describes, it is a first step in a line of research and the development of a prototype of a meta-case application. In this sense, it remains unclear what the current level of maturity is, both of the research and of the developed application.

This paper presents a software tool that is useful in the context of software engineering. The authors do a good job describing the technical details of the tool. However, there is little information about the novel aspects of the proposed tool, How the proposal compares to other existing tools (if any)?
Very clear, precise and high-level work

The article presents the design of a prototype that implements a system for data acquisition through wireless mobile devices, applied to mining, specifically in the monitoring of particulate matter. The application of mobile technology to a specific problem of the Chilean mining industry is interesting; in addition, the article very clearly describes the problem and the proposed prototype. The article is novel since it proposes the use of computing (data processing) and mobile device technologies applied to a specific problem of the Chilean mining industry. The problem, the technology presented (BUG) and the proposed prototype are clearly described. The application of current mobile computing technologies in important industrial sectors of the country is relevant. The main title and summary must be written in Spanish and English (they only come in Spanish). Furthermore, the article presents a list of 29 references, but only refers to one (the first on the list). It even appears in the PCFactory References, and it is not very clear why.

Considers the use of mobile technologies to incorporate the measurement of particulate matter that exists inside a mine. It will be interesting to see the advantages and disadvantages of this application with other existing ones. It is a study only. There are no results yet.

An extensive work is appreciated that is valued, however several inconsistencies are observed throughout the work. On page 4, figure 1, we see the indication of a conceptual model, this being of the snowflake type, however the correct thing would be to indicate that it is a logical design scheme and not a DW conceptual design. Furthermore, a correct conceptual scheme should not indicate the type of data. Also in this aspect, reference is made to a star schema bibliography. There was a lack of research on conceptual models for DW to avoid the above. A lot of redundancy in technical problems that should not be of importance to the article. There is talk of business intelligence but in a strict sense, if business intelligence is applied, an “expert” analyst is needed who is capable of making decisions with the trends found in the study, which is not presented in the article. References to related works are missing, as only books are referenced. A review of related works would have been very useful in the sense of better structuring the article. There are methodologies to outline the ETL process that would have allowed us to improve this aspect described in the article.

The article presents the process of building a data warehouse to implement OLAP on marine resource exploitation data on the coasts of Chile. The problem is clearly defined and has relevant practical application for the country. The work presented corresponds to a very complete and detailed use case of well-known data mining techniques. The ABSTRACT must be edited to represent an appropriate and readable translation of the ABSTRACT. The original contribution of the work is not evident. The original conclusions of the article are related to the application domain (marine resource exploitation statistics) and not to topics relevant to the conference. Missing information in the bibliography should be completed.

The article presents the development of a solution to the problem of analyzing trends in the landing of marine species on the Chilean coastline, using business intelligence tools. a) formatting aspects 1. the English version of the title and summary of the article contains grammatical, editorial, and style errors. 2. Use of capital letters: chile --> Chile national fishing service --> National Fishing Service kettle --> Kettle table 1 --> Table 1 api --> API etc. 3. Figure 2 is not referenced This figure shows --> Figure 10 shows 4. paragraph after Figure 1 is written in 1 column. It must be in 2 columns 5. format does not completely match the Infonor format. b) background aspects 1. The article does not report research results. It is an application of BI techniques to provide online data analysis support. 2. It is weak in terms of the background of processes and techniques used. Although 12 references are listed, only 2 or 3 of them are cited repeatedly. There is no review of related works (cases of BI applications.) 3. Given the orientation of the article, the (potential) use of the results should be much more detailed. In this sense, there must be greater and better interpretation/evaluation by users of the information analysis.

This paper makes a categorization of ways to integrate business rules into a design using the aspect-oriented paradigm and proposes a documentation template for business rules based on said categorization. The paper provides useful information about the particular problem, as well as a reasonable categorization of different aspects in this problem. It is a good starting point for research along those lines. Although the information provided in the paper is extremely relevant for research on this topic, it is insufficient to accept it as a complete and self-contained work. The reason is that the paper focuses on identifying problems and proposing an artifact (the template) that should solve these problems. However, it does not present evidence as to why this template is a good alternative to solve these problems. This requires the elements mentioned in future work, specifically the formal specification and the automatic tool to create templates and map them to AOP. My suggestion is to wait until these elements are ready to complete this paper and submit it to a new conference.

The work presents a viable alternative to solve the problem of changing business rules. It can be improved by adding a little more background to the aspects topic, given that prior knowledge of this topic is assumed, so the paper is not self-contained.

The work presents a methodology to address the complexity of implementing business rules without making changes to the base functionality of a system. It proposes a clear methodology based on documentation through templates to manage and analyze the impact of implementing a business rule via aspect orientation. The reasons presented to indicate that the OA approach to encapsulating the connection between business rules and base functionality is a non-trivial task are general and should be addressed in more depth. It does not present formal evidence that the use of the proposed templates concretely solves a problem. It is suggested to present a problem solved through the tool that is under development that automatically manages the templates. Failing that, demonstrate the application to a specific problem.

It is an article that presents an interesting diagnosis of software development companies in Chile. They incorporate an initial statistical base that gives formality to the work carried out, specifically for determining the base sample for the development of the surveys. However, the statistical data of the results are not part of the work presented. Presentation of statistical results that validate the conclusions presented and the findings found regarding the diagnosis. The authors are recommended to continue the work in order to incorporate the statistical bases trending in companies in the sector in other countries. Other recommendations: Exhaustive review of English and, particularly for the presentation of the article, the translation of this language should be carefully reviewed. Check particularly the title, where there is an error in the first word.

The development of a prototype for a tool for automatic assignment of software requirements between developers is presented. This tool can be very useful for software development teams. It is about making a contribution through this tool to the quality of the products developed. The heuristic used to assign requirements to programmers is not explained. A study of the existing requirements management tools is not presented, demonstrating that there are no alternative tools to the one presented. And if there are alternatives, justify why to develop a new one. The functionalities of the tool are not clearly explained. There is no evidence of the improvement of the process by including this tool, it is only said in the conclusions that "the change in the quality of the process is perceptible" The bibliographic references used are mostly web pages, a bibliographic review is not noted in the databases. of specialized data. The figures are not well distinguished. Bibliographic references do not comply with the established format. You must write in the third person.

- Innovative proposal for requirements planning for a software factory, as a contribution towards improving project quality. - Although the title of the article is oriented towards 'requirements planning', this point is only addressed again when they narrate how they implemented the prototype. - They do not include a conceptual basis that supports the role that requirements management plays in the software development process and particularly in ensuring the quality of the process. - It is not evident how with a contribution to the automatic planning of the requirements for the software factory, this will allow you to reduce your development times (estimated vs. actual) and therefore ensure greater quality. - The relationship that exists between the proposal made within the framework of CMMI is not very clear. The article proposes a requirements planning model, supported by an automatic tool. The prototype they propose is interesting and relevant. I think that the model and method they propose associated with it can be better organized, which is actually the real contribution of the authors. I consider that from a technical point of view it would be important that the analysis of results that they propose with the case study of the bank was done through an interpretation or quantitative comparison, which really shows that with this automatic planning the quality is really being improved. of the process and/or at least the estimate and actual execution of development times will be shorter, a scenario that according to precedents has already been justified in its direct relationship with quality. It is an interesting proposal that can be applied in real cases of requirements engineering management processes. Currently, it would contribute to the reduction of times associated with this phase of software product development, and consequently with the quality of the process. Taking into account that Requirements Engineering has so many problematic causes and actions, which generate software crises and therefore an impact on quality management, it remains an open question as to whether a contribution towards the 'planning' of the requirement will actually achieve a considerable effect, with respect to other causes or crucial points such as 'requirements prioritization', validation and/or its traceability as such. The organization of the document can be improved in the following aspects: - Some of the figures included are not necessary, since they do not really provide anything additional to what is described in the text, and visually they do not say much. - In the 'APARD Design' section they name many technical aspects characteristic of the reference software factories, which do not give greater weight to the intention of the article, nor are they providing truly influential data for the application. - The quality of the figures can be optimized (mainly those that show the internal components of the algorithm and the actions of use of the system - profiles, since they are the ones that show the greatest contribution). - There are several editorial errors that should be reviewed (for example: the use of 'on the basis of', should be changed to 'based on'; 'use is made', to 'it is used'...)

- The APARD tool - The topic associated with requirements and software factory is interesting - The practical case that considers the use of APARD with its advantages and limitations is not detailed - The section that explains the implementation of the APARD solution must be improved - Improve conclusions - The presentation: with spelling and writing errors, written in the first person, figures with very small letters, white letters in figures make it poorly readable, references written in different ways, etc. - It is recommended not to use Wikipedia as a reference for a scientific article. - Author is missing in references 6, topic name is missing in reference 13 - Reference 7 is written with author in a different way than the others and with title before author. - Change “Keywords” to “Keywords”. - According to the format, put at least 5 keywords. - It gives reference in another format, for example, Greenfield and Short (2003) - There is a lot of detail about technologies and tools and products detailed in the APARD Technology Specification section - What does IQNET[z] mean? - I suggest putting the sections that make up the paper in Introduction.

The topic of the article is novel and necessary in the process modeling literature. The work in general presents a poor theoretical development. To carry out the comparison between process modeling techniques, a methodology must be built that effectively shows the advantages of one method over the other. The comparison made between the methods must be presented for a general case, since nowhere does the methodology explain that it is going to be applied to a particular situation. The methodology of the article does not adequately explain the way in which the comparison was developed, it only exposes the decision criteria used in its construction, which does not allow the results obtained to be adequately evaluated. The research question and objectives of the study carried out are not clearly stated.

Justification: It is a work that is not very new, it is a topic that has been studied a lot, especially graphic models. These concepts are incorporated into the CASE tools, even though they are not presented in depth in the document. Perhaps a greater contribution would have been to investigate formal methods and expand the comparative analysis of methods.

This paper is very interesting, I like the idea, and to make it a work publishable in vennue reaching a wider international audience it is necessary to validate the proposed ideas through extensive experimentation with actual data and users, please go ahead.

This work proposes a new approach to support the prioritization of requirements through a process of transforming Use Cases into a dependency graph through the application of IR techniques, Bayesian networks and domain expert evaluation. . A very good work, it presents the integration of several technologies in a clear and coherent way. This paper presents important problems in its formulation. Practical experience papers must provide more than a simple description of the developed system: they must clearly indicate what new knowledge, technique or solution was obtained from said experience. Consequently, a paper of this nature should include, at least, the following essential elements: - An introduction that clearly explains the purpose of the work: (a) the problem that was solved directly or indirectly with practical experience, (b) why the problem is important and non-trivial and (c) why this experience provided new information within said context (not obtained with similar experiences). - Theoretical framework - The description of the system: it should not be a mere enumeration of its components and functionalities, but rather clearly indicate those elements that, during its development, provided relevant information to the problem of the study. - Conclusions: they must be aligned with the elements of the introduction and must be supported by the evidence provided in the system description. Analyzing the paper from this perspective, we found important problems: First, the introduction is not clear regarding the purpose of the work and. The only part where the objectives are mentioned is in the 5th paragraph, where it is indicated that the case study is "to empirically demonstrate the development costs" associated with the technologies shown in the paper. This, along with "highlighting the main features and potential virtues of CakePHP and MVC..." seem to be the central elements of the paper. Second, the system description is not much different from a system manual; Essential evidence is missing to support the elements of the introduction: associated development costs (time, people, resources) which, it is assumed, should be lower than with another methodology. While the sections describing CakePHP and MVC have information relevant to the problem, they do not add value to the work if they are not supported by evidence obtained directly from development experience with this technology. Above all, I missed a comparison with some other similar experience, clearly indicating what development improvements CakePHP/MVC introduces. Finally, the conclusions of the paper are not aligned with the elements indicated in the introduction; some of them provide information out of context (conclusions #5 and #6) or are irrelevant (conclusion #2); others lack evidence to support them (conclusion #1) or are not explicit in associating the evidence with what is concluded (conclusions #3 and #4). Aside from the previous observations, the paper also requires improvements in the presentation of information. For example, the value that the SQL code in figures 10 and 11 delivers to the paper is not explicit. Figures 12-15 are not adequately described. A person who does not understand working with the command line well may end up completely disoriented and will not understand the arguments used. For all these reasons the paper is not in a position to be accepted for publication. Although they mention it as future work, HL7 should be taken into account from now on

Abstract: Needs to have a definition of ERP - can't assume the reader knows what this means.  Intro: Avoid 1 sentence paragraphs (page 1) The introduction is rather long - it seems to actually be two different sections: an introduction (1st four paragraphs) and 1+ page of background and hypothesis. Overall - at 1.5 pages the intro is rather long for a paper that is 4 pages total.  Methodology: I think there are a lot of assumptions in regards to what ERP are and how they work.  While the paper is a statistical study, it would have benefited with a context of an actual example.  The samples are from small to medium size companies (how many?) with 49 use case (how do these relate?).  Results: Discussion is too limited - it assumes that a reader is very familiar with the area, and that may not be the case.

The article presents a study of the perception that requirements engineers (novices and experts) have in relation to the effectiveness of the different eduction techniques for the discovery of requirements in a software development project. The article addresses a topic that deserves some attention given the large number of eduction techniques that exist and the disorientation of requirements engineers regarding which one to use in a given context. The study carried out considers as novice Engineers who do not have knowledge of eduction techniques and one of the attributes that must be qualified as the basis of the comparative study is precisely their experience. In fact, as a conclusion, it is stated that “more extensive training, mainly of a practical nature, is necessary so that new engineers can decide…”, that is a truism. A greater range of context attributes such as those suggested in [14] should be considered to allow more truthful conclusions.

It is a study carried out under a formal methodology (grid technique). The objective behind the study is to improve the preparation of strategies for training in requirements elicitation techniques, which is a contribution given the relevance of Requirements Engineering in software development. The study covers a wide variety of eduction techniques, among which the most used in practice are incorporated. The study was applied to people who belong to a single institution (Polytechnic University of Madrid). This is undoubtedly a limitation since everyone has exactly the same training. It would be interesting to apply the study to new engineers with different training. The conclusions obtained from the study are not new, they confirm what could logically be expected.

The article presented briefly describes the studies carried out and decisions adopted, which allow providing high-capacity infrastructure to the ESO Paranal and Cerro Armazones observatories, located in the Atacama Desert. The various stages involved in the challenge of providing high bandwidth to the aforementioned observatories located in unpopulated areas (full desert) are presented for their expeditious connection with various academic networks and the European astronomical community, which constitutes a good challenge from the technological point of view. It would be important to highlight the need to have large bandwidths, that is, to describe in greater detail the type of traffic that justifies it, for example monitoring, control and remote operation, etc. The link is not yet operational

It presents a work of great relevance to science in Chile, mentioning elements very necessary for the development of high-performance communications in the technological and research poles. It could go into depth with a brief technical description of the technology mentioned in the paper, given that the work is not self-contained.
It is a large-scale project that needs to be known by the academic community. It will include the values of the project in the presentation.

The paper performs a performance comparison for GPU-based and CPU-based implementations for the same algorithm. GPU programming is a very current topic in HPC. There are problems in the presentation of the article and the images are not well contextualized. Implementations and performance comparisons between GPU and CPU are a topic already addressed in existing works. The article describes relatively specifically the implementation and its details, along with the problems encountered. The topic of GPU programming is a very current topic in high-performance computing and its comparison with CPU-based programming seems relevant to me. It would be advisable to improve the order of the article, better relating the images and tables. There are obvious spelling mistakes within the content of the work.

The manuscript involves the use of GPU, a technology that has had more and more to say in the area of HPC for a couple of years. The document is relatively well structured, comparisons are made and there are some interesting graphs. The document has some flaws that make it confusing, for example, page 7 is a complete mess, Figure 7 is not well explained, the tables are treated as figures, there is a difference between what an image and a graph represent, so which must be treated independently. There is a text that explains Figure 6, which by the way is a table, that text is not part of the body of the paper, is it? It is very difficult to read that page. I am not an expert in the SIFT algorithm, so when reading the paper it is not clear to me if they used the SiftGPU code created by Changchang Wu or took it as a base and applied some modifications to it. On the other hand, it would have been interesting to know why the CUDA implementation, the multicore implementation and the serial one could give different results, if after all the three approaches are the SIFT algorithm. I have been programming parallel applications for more than 12 years and for the same algorithm I have never observed different results, if at the end of the day the algorithm is the same, now, when variants are introduced to the original algorithm in order to force parallelism, it is They have different results, but it is no longer the original algorithm. Reading other papers on the subject, I do not find so much originality, the document does not help much in drawing conclusions either. The paper has data from runs and compares different approaches, but I have a big doubt as to why the same algorithm with a sequential approach and another parallel one with GPU can give different results. GPU is a matter that has its advantages, especially because of the money savings that its use implies in the long term, so it could be good to disseminate this work to disseminate this technology. The document is disorganized, it is necessary to differentiate what is a figure, a graph and a table, in addition page 7 is very difficult to read and the explanation of the data tables is confused with the body of the paper.

The article generally proposes an architecture based on the Windows Azure platform to develop applications for Cloud Computing, which is a very current paradigm in computing technologies. Some indicators or comparisons of why use Windows Azure and not other platforms for Cloud Computing applications would be appreciated. The use of Windows Azure for the development of an application for Cloud Computing does not seem very original to me and the proposed architecture is based on MVC, which is widely used in the area of application development. The article describes in a very general way the concepts of Cloud Computing, MVC, Web Services and REST. The topic of Cloud Computing is a current computing paradigm, and from that point of view, the article is relevant. It would be appreciated to define the acronyms at least once, define whether we will speak of "the cloud" or "the cloud", references in the "Proposed Architecture" section and some figures that show the proposed architecture.

- Description of the components of the Windows Azure cloud computing platform. - Succinct description of the concept of cloud computing. - Lack of discussion regarding the possible disadvantages or adverse scenarios of a "cloud implementation" - The summary talks about "...detailing the experience in building a platform to build public and open clouds", but is only limited to the description of the Azure platform. - Very little depth in the description of the application that was set up on the cloud platform. Given the title and summary, more analysis is expected in terms of the advantages and disadvantages of development using this platform. - Writing problems within the work itself. - Certain sections seem more like a commercial brochure than an academic work.

The paper has a relatively coherent structure, it introduces a series of concepts that could be useful for someone who does not know the subject, it talks about architectural patterns and describes windows azure. For someone who knows the subject it is tedious to read already known definitions, on the other hand, the The title of the paper is not consistent with what was written in the manuscript, in fact at times it gave me the feeling of reading a commercial brochure rather than a scientific work, cloud computing and especially its implementations, such as Windows Azure, have advantages and disadvantages. , to mention some disadvantages: loss of control, performance, privacy, in Latin America all countries have serious bandwidth problems, which is why cloud computing can constitute a risk more than a benefit if a basic aspect is not improved, improving data networks. I think that the practical case should have been explained more, since it is the essence that shows whether cloud computing is useful or simply another buzzword that the commercial area of IT companies wants to sell us. The paper is mainly limited to explaining concepts and benefits rather than showing the benefits and qualities through an example or practical case. The practical case is not detailed and application development is not seen from a critical point of view, only positive aspects are mentioned and not negative ones. Although cloud is a current term, after participating in several grid computing and collaborative systems conferences, I am still not clear if cloud is a buzzword in the commercial area or if it really has something new that the concepts that were coined before did not have, although I am missing a critical and objective vision of the subject, in parts it seems like a commercial brochure, I believe that an open discussion of the subject can be generated to help answer the doubts that exist around the term cloud computing. The paper has writing errors in the summary, however, it has coherence and an evolution of the topic, although the topic in which it evolves is not aligned with the title of the document.

The paper introduces a segmentation procedure for breast tissue images using SVM.  General comments:  a) Concerning the proposed approach: The segmentation method introduced only considers local color/gray value information. Perhaps introducing other features related to the membrane's local (e.g. the membrane has symmetry properties that can be exploited) or global (e.g. continuity, approximately circular shape) properties may improve the segmentation results.  Feature selection is also a key component to improve performance. Use a feature selection procedure.  b) Concerning the experimentation: You should describe the experiments with sufficient detail so others can replicate them: a) Make your data publicly available b) Explain how you have selected the classifier's parameters (parameter selection in an SVM is critical and may improve notably the performance).  You should join Figs 10 and 9 in a single plot so we can better see the differences.  You only provide qualitative segmentation results (Figs. 12, 14, 15), but quantitative results are also very important. Specially when it comes to comparisons. You should quantitatively compare your algorithm with other competing works in the literature.  c) Concerning paper organization: The paper is well written and clearly introduces the problem, describes the relevant literature and presents the solution. I have a few comments concerning the paper organization: a) Problem statement and literature review (intro and theoretical framework sections) are in my opinion a bit long, compared to other important sections, e.g. feature extraction and experimentation which are just one paragraph each. b) Although English is in general correct, there are some small mistakes that could be solved by having it read by a professional. c) There are two "proposed method" sections  Well written paper. Good literature review.  It only shows very preliminary results.

This work shows a breast tissue image segmentation approach for the binary classification of pixels of an image using SVM, to determine the presence or absence of staining of the membranes of cancer cells. This work is interesting and valuable, due to the difficulty in obtaining this type of images and the interdisciplinary approach, also presenting interesting future work. It is well written and the results shown, although partial, seem correct and justified. Check the writing and typography of page 4 in its first and penultimate paragraphs. The main weakness of this work may be the low number of test images and the lack of comparison with other methods. It would also be desirable to show general results of the classification and not just the validation process. Furthermore, the properties explained in the scoring table (completeness and intensity) are not used directly in the classification process.

The paper presents a medical test based on images of tissue sections. The approach proposed to cancer cells segmentation (membrane localisation) is based on local pixel features and SVM classification.  The paper describes quite well the practical problem it deals with (cancer cells segmentation on images) and it is generally well written.  - The paper approach described in the paper seems a first try on the problem and follows others in a quite similar (but new) problem. Moreover, the paper concludes that the proposed approach is not good enough.  - The features used for classification lacks of frequency information around each pixel (although it used the first derivative with sobel). Most texture descriptors in the literature use frequency information from gabor wavelets, fourier coefficients, DCT, etc. Why not use this kind of information? Why you have chosen this 7 features and not other ones? The paper lacks of experimental evaluation on different features sets.

The article presented describes how to model a multi-agent system according to the agent-oriented methodology “GAIA” to model requirements traceability. GAIA's proposal to model requirements traceability using Multi-Agent Systems appears to be novel. The presentation of the article is quite confusing, the document presents some spelling, writing and structuring errors, it refers to tables that are figures, unreferenced tables are presented, figure 6 does not exist, the item “results” should be changed or described elsewhere in the document. Insufficient conclusions.

- The article describes several approaches to developing requirements, and applies one of them (GAIA) to the construction of multi-agent systems (MAS). - The Introduction is very long and covers many topics; It should be divided into several sections, leaving only the general context and description of the rest of the article in the Introduction. - There is no example to illustrate the technique, which is described in 1.5 pages, being the essence of the contribution. - There is no validation of any kind.

The use of the GAIA methodology is proposed for traceability to requirements, the proposed approach is based on the social capacity of the agents to process knowledge, perceive changes in the environment and communication. This is a complex task, since in software development a wide variety of models and diagrams are used to facilitate the representation of knowledge; these artifacts are modified over time. These changes come mainly from the user. It is necessary to delve deeper into the practical application of the proposal to better evaluate the scientific and practical contribution.

There are problems in wording and presentation (for example, "it has an IP camera which can..."). Furthermore, it is unclear whether applications have been developed on the framework and whether they function properly.

It shows a mix of web technologies for development and implements a native solution. It does not show how much bandwidth is consumed on the trunks by the application when the cameras are all working together. Need to show more results.

The work presents the development of a web framework for the transmission with the capacity to analyze images from IP cameras. The bibliography presented are web pages related to the tools used for development, but not to related topics or other related applications. Formatting problems (check spelling, line breaks when they shouldn't, indentation, Indicates in the summary that the system has analysis capacity, but at the end it indicates that it is disabled. - The article addresses a relevant and trending problem in the community (e.g. CMMI-ACQ). - There is no state of the art that reviews previous attempts to solve this problem. - The definition of acquisition project patterns should adhere to the usual pattern definitions (especially if compared with design patterns, as done in the Conclusions); e.g. the Portland style of design patterns recognizes context, problem and solution. - The technique used (MECT) seems adequate to build taxonomies, but not patterns (by excluding considerations about causality etc.); the article seems to assume that "design patterns" are "form patterns", and they are not. - Reference [13] lists the author's name incorrectly.

This is a topic that has not been addressed sufficiently and that is why it is good to treat it in a "serious" way. Precisely because of what was stated above, this theme can be "made more use of." Although I consider the classification deduced to be adequate, I think it could have been gone a little deeper.

The article presents an eye detection and tracking system to help clinical psychological analysis. General comments. A lot has been published on the topic addressed in the article. However, no other relevant, directly related works are cited to help us locate the proposal within the literature. A good starting point could be the special issue of the journal: Computer Vision and Image Understanding Volume 98, Issue 1 (April 2005) Special issue on eye detection and tracking The experimental part of the work is very brief. It is important to describe in detail the data used in the experimentation, what the capture conditions are, and even make them public so that other researchers can compare them. As for the results, it is not enough to give a percentage of successes. False positives and negatives must be analyzed and related to the technique used and, if possible, to the future topics to be investigated. Other comments: The article mentions that response speed has been considered, but no figures are provided. In the introduction reference [3] is cited in the related review on the psychological aspects of the article, when this reference appears to be mathematical morphology. Some references are incomplete: + In 1 and 2 the publisher is missing + In 3 the conference/journal. + In 5 the volume, number and pages The article addresses a topic of great technical and practical interest. A system is described that appears not to be fully developed.

The work presents an eye position detection system in development to support the psychological analysis of a person. A way to detect eyeballs and their direction is presented. In addition to a small mention of C/C++, the use of support libraries, such as filters, image capture, etc., is not explicitly specified. It is mentioned that the response speed of the system has been considered, however, no evidence of this factor is presented. The data set on which the study was carried out is not mentioned, whether it is pre-existing or was developed specifically for this work by the authors. Details of the faces in this data set (age, race, sex, etc.) are also not presented. It is not specified whether the results obtained were reviewed by a professional in the clinical area and his conclusions. The references are very few in relation to the field of work carried out.

This work proposes a part of an unfinished system to recognize and interpret eye movement as a support tool for a psychologist. It is an interesting topic. Although it is an interesting topic, the problem to be solved is not well explained nor are the results of the interpretation of eye movement shown. I could have used more sheets to explain this. Formatting problems (writing problems, spelling, there are equations in which the terms are not explained, you must write in the third person) The presentation modality was 4 or 10 pages, however it only presents 3 pages.

This work shows the results of the development of a CBIR based on metric distance indices, comparing it with existing systems through recovery precision and comparing the time efficiency results for different indexing approaches such as GNAT, NAT, etc. The work addresses an important problem of recovery systems, its structure is correct and the results appear to be founded. Perhaps the evaluation criteria are not sufficient to determine the superiority of one approach over another, although the authors recognize the main shortcomings regarding this point and envision future work in this direction. The explanation in section 2.3, on precision, is unclear in defining how we know in advance about the correct images most similar to a query in order to calculate precision. The time graphs in Figure 3 do not indicate the scale.

The article discusses the construction of image retrieval systems based on content (of images), CBIR. The CBIR problem is introduced and some algorithms are presented that allow accelerating the searches for nearest neighbors to an input vector (corresponding to an image) in the feature space chosen to represent the images. Color, frequency response, and global features are used for each of the local frames into which an input image is divided. In this way, information of different types is introduced into the CBIR system to represent the images. - The article does not clearly define its contributions. It seems to add something to the feature space in which images are represented, and it also seems to add something to the algorithms and data structures needed to speed up searches in metric spaces. - In general the article uses little space to explain the proposed approach to CBIR (two references are given to master's thesis). In the conclusions, experimental results are presented, when clearly they should go in a previous section with the experiments. - Regarding the visual characteristics used to represent an image: Experiments are lacking that allow us to establish what each of the characteristics that are proposed to be used contribute. That is, I think it is important to answer the question: Why these and not others? and also to the question: Are any of them redundant and could they be stopped being used? Although it is true that a feature selection procedure is used, an experiment is missing establishing the effect of selection. How much is gained in success rate by using the complete vector? It seems that the feature space after selection has a dimension of 3078 (section 2.4). Is this the case or have the 3078 features been extracted "manually"? - The experiment comparing CBIR systems (section 2.3) is not understood. What is done with the 100 images common to the databases? Is the same query done in all systems and is the precision and recall measured using only the 100 common images when they appear or not in the system's response? That is not explained at all in the article. - When data such as sensitivity and specificity are given in the conclusions, it must be said on which data set it has been tested. It is possible to run a test on some data and obtain a completely different result on others. Therefore sensitivity and specificity without reference to the data from which it was obtained are meaningless. - It seems to this reviewer that an article on CBIR should not overlook developments in Computer Vision based on local features (already classics) such as: Sivic, J. and Zisserman, A. Video Google: A Text Retrieval Approach to Object Matching in Videos Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Computer Vision (2003) D. Nistér and H. Stewénius, Scalable recognition with a vocabulary tree Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (2006) - Some of the references, such as [10,11,13], are incomplete. What do they refer to? An article? An example system running on a URL? - The system running on the URL referred to by the authors gives execution errors when trying to test with images extracted from Google Images.

The publication aims to show the benefits of metric structures for image recovery. This work is the continuation of several works already presented, such as. [1] "Parallel metric structures in image retrieval", Peña-Jaramillo, E. (Referenced in the paper) [2] "Definition of an Image Retriever based on Contents on Metric Spaces", Eduardo Peña-Jaramillo, et to the. (Not referenced). [3] "Parallel Metric Structures in Image Retrieval on the Web", Eduardo Peña-Jaramillo, et al. (Not referenced). Regarding reference number [1], it has not been possible to obtain an electronic copy, and from the aforementioned publications [2] and [3], it can be said that there is a new contribution in the experiments carried out on GNAT and Spaghetis structures. It must be explained in the publication that the work is not original from the author's point of view, and that its extension is based on the works [1], [2], [3] or another that is directly related to the work presented. . - The text is well structured and it is easy to understand what you want to explain. - Good presentation, no serious problems. Just improve the figures in the graphs, especially the accent marks, in Matlab you can add text in latex to avoid these types of problems. The word "more" appears a couple of times without an accent. - In the "Introduction" section, although the work is presented in a general way, I think it would be important to point out the state of the art in these matters. Are there related works? Are there important references? What is the contribution of the work to the state of the art?, etc. A more exhaustive bibliographic review is missing. - In the "Feature Extraction" section I have found some details such as: - It has been difficult for me to find a definition of the layout technique since there is only one reference [1], so I suspect that the characteristics obtained from each sub-image as a signal which are mixed to obtain the vector that represents the total image, as it says in the text: "The union of all the extracted features gives us the result...", where it is not clear the type "union" that is performed. - The same thing also happens when the Fisher discriminant is referenced, again reference is made to [1]. A more relevant source should be added for this point. - The type of database used is not explained in detail. Is it public or private domain? What type of images or groups of images it contains. How many are there per class? Are there repeated images? Image quality. The idea is to have a framework of reference so that anyone who wants to compare their algorithms with yours does so on equal terms. - From the images shown in Figure 2, I can deduce that the database (I hope I am wrong) has repeated images, which can produce a bias when calculating the precision, sensitivity and specificity values of the recovered images. I think that the ideal database to be able to correctly measure the quality of the recovery should have different images even if they have the same appearance, but never the same. Since when recovering a set of images based on a query image, if they are repeated, the number of true positives will be proportional to the repeated ones, which will result in a bias in the calculation of the metrics. Recommendations - In the text it is mentioned (conclusions section) that the solutions are not entirely satisfactory. I believe that currently there are projects such as http://similar-images.googlelabs.com/, http://www.like.com/, http://www.tineye.com/, among others; which show great progress in this field and would be good to be reviewed. - On the other hand, regarding the set of features used, I recommend reviewing other types of features that have been shown to be invariant to scale and rotation. [4] "Distinctive Image Features from Scale-Invariant Keypoints." David G. Lowe. International Journal of Computer Vision, 2004. as well as its improvement [5] "SURF: Speeded Up Robust Features", Computer Vision and Image Understanding (CVIU). Herbert Bay, Andreas Ess, Tinne Tuytelaars, Luc Van Gool. Vol. 110, No. 3, pp. 346--359, 2008.

The article promises to present a method to measure the quality of software development in SCRUM. I consider the proposal interesting and relevant, however the work has weaknesses in its construction. The promise of the title is diluted in the abstract and the introduction, with the “introduction” of SPEM as a tool. Then, in the body of the article, the link between SPEM and the proposed quality measurement method is not clear. The case study on which they are basing their work is also not clear. Modeling in SPEM is about SCRUM in a theoretical way in the case study. The evaluation of the method does not seem to measure the quality of the software, but rather the criteria of those involved regarding adherence to the modeled process. And in any case, it always measures intermediate documents of the process and not defects or primary attributes of the quality of the software produced. Minor comments: - Review the construction of references - SCRUM modeling does not include the retrospective meeting. If you are modeling a particular implementation of SCRUM, clarify this in the body of the paper. Otherwise it is a major modeling error. - Why do they use a traditional process to model an agile process? Couldn't one of the latter have been used? - On the first sheet, at the end of the first column, change the font.

Interesting work that deals with the simulation of urban environments to simulate accidents and measure the effects of urban interventions that help in their prevention. The work is a contribution both from the point of view of its objective, and from the detailed description it makes of the process of integration of technologies that allowed it to be carried out, which can be replicated for projects that use 3D technology with other objectives, as well as the strategies used to refine the model through hot air balloons. What is missing, however, is a review of similar works to have established a comparison.

This is an interesting work, where the author wants to show Honeynets as an alternative security measure, to learn how intruders operate and thus create new forms of protection. Observations: - The name of the sole author must be centralized in the article. - Words and figures in English. The article is in Spanish. - The references are inadequate: there is only one article cited and with an incomplete reference. Improve the bibliographic review, citing current articles and books.

SUMMARY. The work describes the steps to follow to apply fuzzy logic concepts on mobile devices. To exemplify the steps to follow, the author used a mobile robot called AMADEUS (similar to the cleaning robots marketed in Japan [1]). To apply the concepts of fuzzy logic, the Mamdani module was used. General evaluation. The topic is very interesting and very recurring lately. Devices that use fuzzy logic to operate are a very interesting and innovative bridge between Artificial Intelligence and "pervasive computing". However, this work has at least one important weakness that should be resolved: 1) The work does not show why it is really important to use fuzzy logic. An example application is strongly recommended for work. How would using fuzzy logic on mobile devices help? 2) At work it is not very clear to me if the use of fuzzy logic on mobile devices is something new in this area. If it is not something new, perhaps the work could become just a repetition of other work. If it's something new, please mention it. Minor Comments: - In the conclusions, the phrase "it was demonstrated" is mentioned; it is suggested to change to "was shown". - Be careful with the use of punctuation (e.g. "...", ".") and capitalization. - At the end of the introduction, it is suggested to mention the structure of the document. [1] Auto Mee: www.yumeki.org/comercilizaran-pequeno-robot-limpiador-de-dispósitos-tactiles
This article is not a research article as it only shows how to program a robot using the fuzzy logic tool. This issue has already been proposed as a solution in robot navigation.

The work, according to the reviewers, does not present a direct scientific contribution in the area of robotics or fuzzy systems, however it is a very interesting application to be presented at the INFONOR 2013 Robotics Workshop. That is why it is recommended to accept the article for presentation.

This article proposes a system that adds fuzzy components to certain attributes of a database with information about the physical state of people. The application of the work is interesting, since there are few experiences where fuzzy attributes are used in practice for storage and consultation in our country, so it can make the topic discussed interesting for our congress. However, the following aspects are either not clear or incomplete: - Use the format requested by the congress. - Improve the general writing of the summary/introduction - Write point 3, 4.1.1 in the third person when referring to the client - Be careful with the use of abbreviations that are sometimes used in lowercase or capital letters - Write the conclusion with an approach where it is left It is not clear what benefits the user of the system obtained with respect to a non-fuzzy system - It is not clear how the membership functions used were determined. - There is a lack of some type of study/comparison to verify the contribution that a system like the proposed one improves or complements a traditional system in the applied area. Due to the above, it is recommended to accept the article for presentation at the Business Applications Workshop.

A Learning Object serves as support to the educational process, to develop competencies in students in one of the three types of knowledge (conceptual mastery, procedural mastery and development of attitudes and values). In none of these areas is there evidence to prove it. In addition to the fact that the experiences are very basic, the abstract, I quote it verbatim: "The Article presents the experiences collected from the application of Learning Objects in the development of the subject of Introduction to Automata Theory, because in the development of the course, significant changes have been deployed, proposing detailed and exhaustive academic monitoring through a “Quick Feedback” and “Short Questions” scheme.", the experiences collected are not shown nor is it mentioned how they would obtain them.

The need to use Learning Objects (LO) for teaching the course "Introduction to Automata Theory" is presented. However, there is very little information dedicated in the article to the LOs chosen for the course, there is no information on the results of their application or their consequences (learning results, student survey to validate it, etc.). That is why it is not recommended to accept the article, unless information is added that supports the application of OA in this course.

The article is interesting because of the topic it addresses and the results of the analyzes carried out, more than because of the methodology itself. I have questions about how the analyzes are fed with new information and how the system is integrated into the USACH transactional systems. However, it is an interesting application.
