- The topic is of scientific relevance. - In the work, an analysis of the literature on data quality in municipal e-government applications was developed. - Methodologically there are three important limitations to overcome. First, the impact factor of the publications has not been considered, which has rejected the development associated with this type of reviews, mixing high-impact works (for example, articles from ISI journals with an impact factor >2, such as MISQ). with works without a quality review (for example, what Scholar "releases" just to match the search). Second, it is said that references from 2008 onwards will be taken as a priority, but many of their references are from before that date, and that is not unusual, since between 2001 and 2004 there is an explosion of work in this specific field. The paper shows a practical application developed with augmented reality applied to delivering tourist information in open spaces. The article presents a case study on the development of an augmented reality mobile application. In the central section of the article (Proposed Solution) there are multiple sections where concepts are mixed: selection of tools, design of the application architecture, list of functionalities (which must be reviewed to be an extension of the requirements of section III) . I suggest separating and selecting just one of these aspects to discuss in greater depth. For example, the selection and justification of tools is scattered at various points in the article. There is an opportunity to explain the lessons learned from developing an AR application in greater detail. The list of benefits and discussion of results is only about general aspects. I suggest including more references to the literature on AR: definitions, recent research, cases of similar developments.

This article presents the development of a SYN-FLOOD AND SATAN attack detection system using clustering techniques based on the DBSCAN algorithm in time windows of 5 minutes. The article is presented clearly in its writing and the summary of designed architecture is appreciated, and it could be an interesting article to be presented at our congress. My main objections are: - Figure 7 presents graphs with a 10-minute window, while the proposal indicates 5 minutes - In my opinion the system does not represent a data mining process because there is no new actionable knowledge, but rather It is a classification system. There may be new knowledge, but the document does not reflect how the system created helped obtain new knowledge of the attacks. - There is little explanation and lack of experimentation to argue and justify the use of DBSCAN over another type of clustering or even instead of a classifier. - It is known that a SYN-FLOOD attack produces a high number of connections at a given time, so it is not clear if such a sophisticated system is necessary to detect this phenomenon. This could be clarified if a comparison with other approaches were included. .

SUMMARY. The work proposes a model to evaluate the quality of agent-oriented software. Basically, the model considers three properties to evaluate its quality: social ability, autonomy and pro-activity. To evaluate these properties, the author decomposes these properties into several measurable sub-properties. The author evaluates this model through a case study: a banking system. General Comments: In a notary way, the structure of the document has the necessary aspects to be considered a scientific article. The contribution of the article seems to be relevant. That said, this work lacks some points that (for me) are important to address: * The author mentions that there is no model to evaluate the quality of agent software, and he proposes one. His proposal is an adaptation of ISO/IEC, however, the author does not justify why it is appropriate. * Regarding the previous point, paragraph 1 of the introduction says that there is no model that measures software quality. Then, paragraph 2 mentions that there is some work about this. The author should clarify his contribution. * The author mentions that software was developed for this work, however, this work appears as just another publication (and by another author). If the software mentioned is not part of the work contributions, please remove these phrases. Other comments: * In the case study section it is not so easy to understand it. For example, figures 2, 5 and 7, it is not clear what their acronym refers to (e.g. AMS). I suppose they correspond to the sub-properties. * It is recommended to exchange section 3 for section 2. That is, first explain what an agent is and then talk about the related work. * It is not clear to me if it is "software agent" or "software agent". The author also confuses this terminology (first sentence of section 4).

The work presents an interesting proposal to evaluate the agent-oriented software development paradigm and although it is a work in progress, it has good foundations. It is suggested to rewrite the Summary so that it is more understandable, using nouns again when necessary and with a less rigid structure.

The work is well presented, consistent and deals with a relevant problem. The results presented are still incipient, because the case study is simple and does not incorporate major complexities. Even so, I consider that this work presents sufficient elements for its acceptance.
A CityCA model is proposed, based on cellular automata for distribution. The paper is well written and well distributed, perhaps organizing the abstract a little would make it better understood.

This is a quite particular article that proposes an extension to existing data models considering the idea of ​​"system" (of objects). For this, a language (LATIN) and a universal data model are proposed, MED, based on a "spherical volume" with two poles "major" and "daily" based on accounting ideas. This is, in my opinion, the most critical aspect of the proposal, since the doubt arises as to whether every system should fit into this scheme, or whether we are talking about a particular set of cases. The subsequent ideas are interesting and, at least, generate a break with respect to the classic ideas of object orientation. I quote the idea of ​​a proposed system: "a system is a set of linked and inter-acting classes according to the same method, which is not particular to each class but emergent from all of them." Other ideas associate transaction with a referential set, macros, types, instances,... which in global terms constitute a new body of ideas. There being no citation in the references to any previous article by the author that deals with these ideas, it seems to me that it may be interesting to listen to this proposal and debate about it. In terms of formality, the article does not fully comply with the conference format, and the number of pages exceeds the eight requested.

The article is about the application of BPMN to understand a business process in a mining company in Peru. The document is well structured and easy to read. Few editorial errors are observed. Furthermore, its format is that required by Congress. In relation to the topic of the article, being an application of BPMN, it is not new. From the case, I believe that it was possible to make a greater contribution, perhaps proposing a methodology to address the review of business processes, considering that the internal and external actors of the company generally prioritize the optimization of their production processes more than the review. of other processes. Last but not least, the emphasis of the article is the review (audit) of the process with BPMN, moving away from the themes of the congress. Greater emphasis could be given to applications associated with the congress, such as requirements analysis from BPMN, SOA implementation from BPMN, process monitoring with BAM and BPMN, etc. In some figures, although contractors are mentioned as an external entity, a “lane” is not used to represent them and thus observe the interaction with the process under review. The proposed future work is related to the results obtained from the improvements implemented from the analysis carried out in this work. I think that more than following the improvements implemented, it is convenient to follow up on the way in which the review of a process is approached in an environment that does not prioritize this type of tasks or is complex to carry out.

A small and simple set of BPMN elements was used to model the business process. This experience is valid, but it is an ad hoc solution for the chosen business process. The solution would have a higher value if a small model had been presented that could be validated and that could solve a specific set of business processes associated with mining. Make a good comparison of the technical characteristics of some DB managers in this area (table 3). However, it only establishes a simple and qualitative comparison of components and other aspects such as services (table 4). There is no evidence of a quantitative and objective comparison, at the level of performance and with data, transactions and processing times that allow us to really maintain, as it does without these variables, which DB is more efficient compared to another. The summary does not match or identify the complete work. Conclusions are drawn based on characteristics and not on comparative performance tests. In summary, it is a work from the point of view that would be a contribution if it formalized the methodology and described the quantitative application of an experimentation that truly allows comparing DBMSs in a cloud-computing context. It is suggested to complement with a controlled experiment with data and records of test transactions and measure variables, obtaining objective statistics that allow evaluating the performance of mobile DB and NoSQL systems, under clearly defined conditions and parameters and in the same environmental conditions. (bandwidth, transaction rates, data volume, equipment, etc.).

The article presents a comparative work between the use of a classic relational SABD and a temporal SABD (the English translation temporary seems not appropriate: temporal or time oriented seems more correct). The example presented in the article is interesting and motivating, it is adequately supported and gives rise to comparison, as indicated "it is necessary to define a test scenario where there is a specific application that can be evaluated with the implementation of the paradigms to be compared" . There are two aspects in which the article is not clear, and that detract from its weight: 1) The temporary sabd technology: pgFoundry, it is indicated that it is an extension to PostgreSql. However, no further information is given... when searching for it it seems like a closed project??? How did you work with this extension? 2) Table 3 should be the focus of the article, however it does not describe how many of the comparisons were made. This remains like a black box. What criteria were used in the comparisons? In the conclusions there are some clues, but there are unclear sentences such as: "Greater data entry flexibility can be found in the RDBMS, since there are more types of sources to populate the databases." What do you mean by that?

This article presents a comparison, based on a list of criteria, of two database approaches: relational vs. temporary. The article in general has a logical order and is readable. However, the comparison has at least two drawbacks: 1) there is a lack of much information on how the results in tables 3 and 4 were obtained. There must be a sufficiently detailed description to then be able to replicate the work. 2) The case study presented forms the basis of the comparison. A real comparison must be based on a variety of cases and domains, in order to then conclude on a broader basis. I suggest addressing these two aspects first to better support the results and conclusions.

Abstract: This work describes an experience of using "graphic" language in a school. Evaluation: The topic of the work is interesting, however, a) the job description is weak and b) the results seem non-repeatable. For example for a), the description does not show any image of how the language works (remember that it is a graphical language). A scratch example is strongly recommended to introduce the language. For example for b), there is no clear description of the configuration of the experiments, the results to be measured and a table to easily appreciate the results obtained. Minor details: a) The beginning of the abstract is super complex to understand b) An excessive use of "this is" c) some misspellings like "question" d) Very long sentences.

Background: - The language to be used after Scratch is mentioned in a very superficial way, perhaps it is not necessary or the topic should be delved deeper into. - The number of students on which the study was applied is too small to obtain conclusive results. - A comparison or study between the use of Scratch and Alice (mentioned in the work) would be desirable. - Concluding from the experiment that Scratch is an appropriate tool for education in Chile, without including results with other languages, is a bit hasty. - It would be desirable to mention that institutions or works related to languages ​​to promote logical thinking have been carried out in Chile. None are mentioned as a reference or in the bibliography. - The exercise used in the experiment is only one, more should be used if you want to objectively evaluate its use as a language to improve logical reasoning. - The first quote comes from a Colombian news portal and from 2006. A more solid and local reference would be desirable, perhaps associated with the guidelines and study plans of the Ministry of Education. Form: - The abstract must be rewritten: it has many words separated by commas and the writing includes ideas disconnected from each other. - Quote 7/8 is cited 8 times. With half of them the reference is clear. - ".. but few learn to program .." should be: ".. but few learn to program .." - Quote 2 says .. "Fundamentals of Programming".. should be: ".. Fundamentals of Programming".

The article presents an interesting development of a case, as another proposal for a starting methodology for teaching programming logic. The conclusions presented do not have much basis in terms of achieving the objective of inducing logical reasoning in this way.

The authors make a comparative analysis between various technologies for industrial automation. I found the analysis reasonably deep and broad, but I rated it as "weak accept" for not having strong scientific contributions. The text needs to be revised, there are long sentences (for example the second of the second paragraph of the introduction has 11 lines) and punctuations are missing or incorrectly placed. The first sentence of the second paragraph of the introduction. Also include the meaning of the acronyms PLC and PC.

Although the topic of automation is of interest, this article has a very general approach. It would be interesting, for example, to refer to compact vs. compact PLCs. Modular PLCs could also be incorporated into the comparison with high-end microcontrollers, given that by providing them with a power stage, very interesting application results can be achieved at low cost. The title tends to confuse given that the presentation of the latest technologies used in industrial automation is expected and rather it focuses first on a historical review of the advances in the area and then dedicates itself to comparing only two of the existing types of controllers. in the industry. The content presented is frequently found in the literature referring to the area, so in my opinion it does not represent a relevant contribution to the topic.

The article presents an application of pattern recognition techniques to the classification of wood types based on audio records. In terms of form: The article presents several syntax problems of the Spanish language, which are easily correctable. The summary should be reviewed and improved. Some English terms are also presented that should be replaced by their meaning in Spanish (e.g. test). Equations 4 and 5 contain errors and should be better explained. Also adjust the font size. Table 1 contains redundant information, since the quantities presented appear to be independent of the method. Improve the resolution and increase the size of figure 5 (to occupy the 2 columns), since it is not possible to clearly appreciate the different points and clusters that are discussed. In the substantive aspects: The review of the state of the art is weak, and more relevant current references related to pattern recognition based on audio data should be incorporated (although they are not necessarily in the domain of wood). The version of the KNN algorithm whose pseudocode is shown is incorrect. It must be reviewed and corrected. It is not appreciated that it works for a certain K. The recursion is not appreciated either. More information and detail of the data and derived characteristics is required.

The work addresses the problem of autonomous navigation of mobile robots by defining a reactive control architecture. The authors should be clearer in stating why to use a reactive architecture, relative to other available approaches. It is necessary to improve the readability of the equations. The work is correct and relevant. The field of mobile robotics has multiple applications. It is necessary to incorporate some guidelines on future work.

The work does not present anything new nor does it contribute to the state of the art. The classification methods it uses are very basic, there are many more effective techniques. Popular and best techniques are also not discussed in the literature. There are no clear hypotheses. What are you trying to "prove" in the experiments? The contribution is not appreciated. Paper organization problems The work is very focused on describing "functionalities" of a system, and not the contribution itself in comparison to the state of the art. Discussing the impact of this on the measurements. The results section can be improved with a more defined structure, treating error results, false reading by reflection, cell wall mapping separately.

The article presents a case of application of an architecture for the control of mobile robots. First, the advantages of the behavior-based approach are presented and then an application case for wall tracking – obstacle avoidance in a robot. The article is well written, but the description of the case or experiment could be improved. It would be desirable to previously establish the objectives for the observation. The variables used could be presented in a graph. Although an improvement from the inclusion of the fuzzy logic module is mentioned, it could be further discussed by discussing the impact of this on the measurements. The results section can be improved with a more defined structure, treating error results, false reading by reflection, cell wall mapping separately.

Although the topic regarding the problem of autonomous navigation of mobile robots is of interest, the work presented does not necessarily have to be. However, as the reader approaches the document in depth, it is possible to realize that the work presented constitutes a contribution to the topic. From the title, what the reader will find in the document is clearly stated, which is reinforced by a simple approach to the topic by the author, facilitating the understanding of the work carried out. On the other hand, a prototype is presented whose implementation can be replicated in the laboratory by anyone interested in the topic, which contributes to this work being considered as a possible reference in the educational field.

I do not agree with what is written in the second paragraph of the introduction. A solution to an NP-complete problem, for example the traveling cashier, can be programmed in a simple way... the problem is that the program's response can take a long time. To circumvent this, heuristics or meta-heuristics are sought that may not find the ideal answer but a good answer. On page 3, notice that Pa is not an element of A and is a subset of A or more precisely a subset of A-{a}. In that same paragraph he talks about "two types of restrictions" but the second is not explicitly placed. At the end of the paragraph it would be interesting to say that "that is, ai belongs to Paj." The sentence is very long: 16 lines! Unclear from Figures 1 and 2 is the restriction that “the sum of the amount of resource type k used in period t, Rk(t), must not exceed Rk.” In the mathematical formulation of the RCPSP it is not clear what it would mean, for example, for Fj to take the value 5 and the meaning of pj and A(t). There was a lack of a statistical comparison of how good the quality of the solution found with the proposed algorithm is from other solutions or at least a comparison that shows how far the solution found is from the ideal one. The references do not seem to have a logical order (alphabetical or citation order).

The work is TOO preliminary: there are no experiments and therefore no results or analysis. The work only focuses on making a discussion of optimization methods for the problem in question. Subsequently, it only defines known and generic formalisms for the problem. The paper is VERY weak, it still requires A LOT of work to be a manuscript with any relevance!

The work presents an approach for project scheduling using the bee colony algorithm. The work, even though it is well written, lacks the application of the algorithm, it does not present one or several application examples. It shows the methodology, defines the problem well, but does not show an example of application of the algorithm. Figure 2 shows a possible solution to a given example, but does not indicate whether it is through the proposed algorithm or another method. The contribution of the research, nor the results, is not clear.

The work is well prepared technically. Its structure and writing make it easy to follow. However, I have doubts about its scientific contribution since it is the application of modeling to a case study. It is not clearly established what the problem to be solved is. Aspect-oriented methodologies have been successfully applied for some time and information from previous work to attack the gap is not provided either. I think we must distinguish why the application of UML (and not other techniques) is necessary to solve it.

The article proposes the application of UML Class Diagrams Oriented to JPI Aspects. In general, the article is well presented and there are no major observations. What's more, there is a concern for making a good presentation of the work. I would only make some minor suggestions, especially with the methodological aspects that should be a little more detailed.

The article complies with the established format and has updated bibliographic references. It is not clearly explained what JPI is, the objective of the article is not clear. The article is a description of the application of the JPI concept, which is not well developed, it is not clear if the authors are the ones proposing this new strategy or are applying a proposal from other researchers. The writing can be improved. It is suggested that the article be extended so that all the concepts, scope and objectives of the research are clearly explained.

The article describes the concepts of data mining and the steps that a KDD process carries out in general, and the latter is associated with social networks and in particular with Facebook, presenting them as its own adaptation, which lacks foundation and logic. For example, it mentions social networks where users express tastes, feelings and other states, which are generally presented in text, and on the contrary it does not indicate anything regarding the processing of text to determine the frequency of words and thereby achieve determine the topics of conversation of a group of users on the network. It also describes some data mining techniques and mixes web mining, perhaps trying to combine different mining methods, which would be the most logical if you want to cover different aspects of social networks, that is, text content, the KDT process should be used. and not KDD, for managing associations or links, mining the web structure, etc. On page 9 he points out that he used the iconic representation technique to visualize results, however there is no evidence of this experimentation in the entire work. Finally, in the conclusions it talks about a developed guide which is not explicit anywhere in the article. It should also be noted that it has some writing errors, repetition of articles and words.

It is a well written article that gives an idea of ​​how to use data mining techniques on social networks like Facebook. It is a current and intriguing topic. But I felt a lack of more concrete things, that is, a concrete implementation of one of the aforementioned techniques applied to Facebook or another social network. The phrase "which can convert data whose storage is unnecessary." on page 3 it seems unfinished. Convert to what?

The article describes some general aspects of the application of data mining to social networks. The review of information is not complete and is far from being considered the state of the art on the subject. I suggest first reviewing articles from journals indexed on the topic, identifying a specific research problem, where a contribution can be made to the topic, and presenting a research proposal.

Corrections to article: “Information management, a continuous challenge of technology.” General evaluation The work is interesting but there is some lack of implementation, since in general it is a good review of the existing literature. Reading the article gives the impression that something is missing (implementation). A scheme should have been proposed with the proposed model and that would make the good intention of the research that will be done in the future clearer. The work is currently a review of the literature with the presentation of a research intention. A better title would have been a review of the state of the art in……ABC or indicate model proposal XYZ Format Corrections Verify the order requested by Ingeniare magazine, regarding references.

The article is very well written and easy to read, basically having the characteristics of a popular article. Aspects focused essentially on information retrieval problems in the face of exponential data growth are discussed. The proposal made at the end of the article is interesting, although, from my point of view, the inclusion of the Big Data topic is given somewhat lightly and requires a more detailed analysis than what is described.

The article addresses a topic of interest such as the management of big data and its structure based on metadata for processing in the era of the semantic web. The article presents serious lexical and even semantic deficiencies. The translation of the title and abstract in English has serious errors. On the semantic aspect, in the introduction they mention as a problem that relational databases do not have adaptation problems. As a lexical error, they write A un, instead of Still. The term Apropósito is mistakenly used instead of On Purpose. The conclusions do not allow us to focus a proposal. There is good use of bibliographic references.

In its form, it has some problems, for example on page 5, in the description of the implemented laboratory, the proposed structure with six cameras to locate the robots on the field during a soccer game is described, pointing out that this is shown previously and [9] appears, where neither figure nor reference exist. On the other hand, in the middle of the bibliographic references, figure 14 appears, which is not referenced in the document. In its content, over 50% of the article is dedicated to the analysis of position and movement capture techniques by image triangulation, repeatedly discussed in the technical literature and which do not provide value from a scientific point of view. It is just a bibliographical compilation of vision techniques. On the other hand, the description of the results is not a contribution to the topic of the article, which is the use of vision technique to determine robots dedicated to soccer. Finally, I think that the author of the article was very lax when writing it, where he should have at least reviewed it before sending it.
Very good article to understand the spatial location of objects, for control purposes, in this case applicable to a set of robots in a soccer game.

I find it an interesting article to consider, although its final objective is somewhat obscure: "measure the position of a robot on a soccer field." In particular, it is not clear if the work is aimed at a more ambitious subsequent goal (multiple robots, equipment movement in real time, and what to finally do with this data???). From what can be deduced, although it is not explicitly stated, measurements were made of "a" robot "placing" it in different positions in the field, but not with it moving in real time. Thus, results are presented, which could have been obtained with another more classic configuration of the computer vision area (the contribution of the robot and the soccer field, at least until now, do not have a fundamental relevance in the work developed). Finally, it does not seem to me that the results obtained are strictly novel, but it can still be an attractive experience to know.

The work presents a survey of two mining companies about the architecture stage of the IT outsourcing process. The work is exploratory and therefore its contribution is reduced since results have not yet been presented. I think that in this state it is inappropriate for the conference where the presentation of results and contributions to research is expected. The document must be improved in terms of its writing.

The name of the article is “How does it affect…”, and it indicates in its Summary “…applied through a case study to two mining companies in the Antofagasta region and a supplier-type company.” However, the article does not present a section with the indicated case study, which indicates that it is not possible to answer the question expressed in the title of the article. Therefore, what has been expressed is good intentions, but there is no empirical evidence. The topic is very important, the form of solution is also appropriate, but everything is expressed in theoretical terms. It is indicated that "the investigation is currently in the stage of conducting interviews", therefore, no analysis of the data or results and conclusions have been carried out. The Results section does not present results. It will be an interesting article when all the stages of the proposed methodology are fulfilled. Some minor observations and/or comments: - References [6] and [13] were not used in the text. - The first paragraph of the State of the Art is a repetition of the second paragraph of the Introduction. - On page 3, change “key activities” to “key activities”. - The Figure on page 6 has no title.

The article presents an introduction to the investigation of the effect of IT Outsourcing in mining in the second region, but does not show concrete results. In the same article it is indicated that the investigation is not completed. It would be interesting to have the complete analysis of the results.

The article has two main contributions: a discussion on the usefulness of SCADA controls on mobile devices, a description of some of the specific applications that implement this function on cell phones or tablets. There are several writing errors throughout the article. For example, separators are used at the end of phrase _, but not consistently. The first and last sentences of the abstract seem poorly written. In the final paragraphs of the introduction the lists are not clearly explained. Although it is relevant for the conference to review mobile SCADA applications, a search mechanism is not defined, nor a criterion to compare them. What are their differences? Which is appropriate in each case? It is suggested to include a comparative table of its features, and more importantly, define comparison criteria in order to provide new data to the reader. The conclusions return to the introduction but do not answer what applications should be used in the context of the mining industry.

The article presents a theoretical analysis of SCADA systems. There is no evidence on the application in a case study. The Summary is not adequate, nor is the introduction. The Results section and the Conclusions section do not present contributions for a scientific article or that shows business experiences in ICT applications. References [3], [5] and [7] are by the same author, same title and same date. The same goes for References [4] and [6]. Reference [1] is not used in the text.

The application of SCADA systems for mining is something interesting but the work is only limited to mentioning mobile tools and there is no clear point of comparison between them. The specific contribution of these tools in a real mining process is also not clear. There are consistency problems in the summary and introduction. The conclusions are not convincing enough, and there are also some editorial problems.

The work presents a state of the art regarding UWSN underwater sensor networks and underwater autonomous mobile robotics. In particular, it describes the problem presented, providing topologies, strategies and hardware for communication. The text is very descriptive, not very analytical and critical, generating little contribution and value, beyond a bibliographic compilation.

The work consists of a survey-type article or study on the subject of networks and underwater vehicles, a bibliographic and related technology review that is very interesting and complete in my opinion. I suggest that you could provide a contribution based on this study, for example providing a taxonomy of the characteristics of the technologies required for this type of problem-solution pair, and adding a proposal through an implementation and testing methodology. The above is indicated as a delivery in future work, perhaps at least a comparative table of the associated and described technologies should have been delivered.
It is a good work, well written, it deals with a new topic in aquatic sensor networks, it will report the tests in more detail and the effectiveness in the application.

The article presents an experiment that compares different navigation architectures for a mobile robot. The architectures (algorithms, approaches) used are described, as well as the metrics defined to evaluate navigation performance. The results are statistically analyzed using analysis of variance. The article is well written and the experiment is presented clearly. The bibliographical references seem to be adequate. The introduction correctly justifies the comparison objectives and generally describes the possible approaches to robot navigation. The selection of metrics is justified and attempts to go beyond a combination of simple measurements. The experiment is well described, although it could be explained why other obstacle configurations were not included in the observation. Statistical methods (analysis of variance) are correctly applied, although an analysis of normality in the distribution could be included. One of the weak points of the work is that a more in-depth discussion of the results is needed. Beyond indicating that one of the architectures has better performance, the reasons should be discussed and new conjectures made. Generalization of the results and discussion of threats to validity should be part of the discussion. For example: What type of obstacles does each algorithm improve on? What is the programming effort for each of the architectures? What are the robot's high-level navigation goals (deliberative behavior)?

The interest caused by the problem of robot navigation is undeniable, so the work presented constitutes an alternative for the choice of the control architecture, since it proposes a possible solution to the problem through the comparison of metrics, however it must Keep in mind that it has been carried out in a simulation environment, under certain conditions that will not necessarily be replicated in practice, which in my opinion restricts the scope of application of the results obtained. On the other hand, the references and development of statistical calculations validate the results obtained with consideration of the environment in which the test was carried out. Well-developed work, although there is a need to carry out tests with the real mobile, under various conditions of the robot's environment, to validate the results obtained in the simulator.

The work compares four autonomous navigation architectures for mobile robots, pure reactive architectures, neural networks, fuzzy logic and a hybrid neuro-fuzzy architecture. The work is well planned, the experimental work seems replicable and the results presented sound coherent. The main aspect to improve would be the analysis/discussion of the results, which can be developed further.

The article presents a research plan that proposes combining the theoretical constructs of technology management competencies (with the BTM model) and the perception of professional success (with a proposed model that combines several factors from various sources). IT management capacity is a key element for professionals in the area and not just their technological skills. It seems relevant to study how these competencies impact professional success, or, at least, the subjective perception of said success. The study contains references to relevant sources, although it is suggested to reduce the number and prioritize in the case of articles in magazines or conferences. Although the topic is relevant, there are some risks in the definition of the constructs that are not analyzed. What are the limits between the perception of professional and personal success? Can a study of the perception of professional success be carried out only considering the BTM model and leaving out technological competencies? Does the study apply to all IT professionals or only to those who manage technological projects like CIOs? The main weakness of the research is that it is identified as an experimental method, when in reality the survey does not have the degree of control over the object of study to be classified in this way. There is also talk of a causality study, but the survey would only allow a co-relationship study. The survey explains the factors evaluated and the Likert scale. However, there is a lack of examples of specific questions and an explanation of how they will be answered by the subjects. For example: Is it feasible for a person to evaluate their commitment or leadership? Although the relationship is being evaluated in general terms and not in its own terms, it would be advisable to first carry out a validation of the model and then the survey itself with a group of experts or managers of IT professionals.

The article shows the design of a research on the impact of IT skills on the perception of professional success, but it is not what it indicates in its title. There is a section corresponding to an extensive review of previous works and definitions, compared to the section that shows the research design, which is quite brief. In my opinion, it was convenient to have presented the article as a systematic review of the existing literature on the topic in order to find gaps and/or similarities in the research design, or to have placed more emphasis on the latter. Although the topic may be new, the article does not demonstrate it, since it is only the presentation of a research design. In the conclusions section, no specific conclusions are shown from the work carried out, only possible scenarios for future work are presented. Regarding the form, the article is well structured, but there are details that need to be corrected: - abuse of “IT” - in some paragraphs previous works are indicated without being referenced - the figure of the model is very basic (it is not a contribution ) - paragraphs not aligned (justified) - figure 1 should have been a table - error in the correlation of figures

This article aims to identify the impact of IT business competencies on the perception of professional success. The problem, the analysis model, the hypothesis and the research methodology are presented. It is an interesting topic, but the author indicates that the research is in the data collection phase and that there are about 7 months left to obtain the final results. However, the theoretical analysis carried out is quite important. Figure 3 is very simple. I suggest that the proposed model provides more information. To do this, you can join Figures 3, 4 and 2 into a single figure. Use numerical references and references in APA format (you must use only numerical references and correctly). There are 2 pages with page number 3. On page 5 appears Figure 4, on page 6 appears Figure 2? Does Figure 3 exist? Reference [11] does not indicate the name of the conference, Reference [15] does not have a date, Reference [30] is it a book?, Reference [34] has its title written entirely in capital letters, Reference [45] says only “Fifth”, Reference [46] says “Second”. In Conclusions, change “thesis q del” to “thesis del”. Change “will be shown” to “will be shown”. References [8] and [46] are not used in the text. The name of the author and institution should be anonymous (according to congressional regulations). On page 5, you should check that the text is right justified. On page 8, change “be capable” to “be capable.”

I find it an interesting job, with an emphasis on covering practical gaps. Its content and structure are technically well presented. However, on the other hand, there is no clear distinction between previous works and the original proposal of this work. The article states that there is previous work regarding this CMMI-ÄGIL pairing but does not indicate whether these proposals are sufficient or insufficient for improvement. That is, the motivation or justification for this work is not explicit.

The article provides a general description of the CMMI model and agile methodologies, taking Scrum and XP as particular cases. A discussion is carried out on the combination of these approaches for process improvement, mapping the REQM and PPQA process areas with their equivalents in agile methodologies. The article provides correct general descriptions of the methodologies, but does not contain novel research elements that contribute to knowledge in this area. For the technical/scientific software engineering community, it is evident that the approaches have different starting points, but they are combinable. This is especially true for software process improvement experts. The review carried out on the research on the combination of agility and CMMI is not systematic. By state of the art we do not mean a simple description of each approach, but rather collecting the most up-to-date research on this topic. Although it may be interesting to map between process areas and agile practices, it is not explained what steps will be followed to do this. There is also no validation of this mapping or an explanation of how it can be applied, for example by a process improvement consultant. No empirical evidence of the applicability or usefulness of mapping is provided.

The article presents a description of the integration between CMMI and agile development methods. An emphasis that the authors make is that this integration is recommended for SMEs. Software development for smaller companies is an unsolved challenge. As such, the authors take a topic that is interesting and justify the idea of ​​the topic well. However, I think they fail to develop their point in the way that would be expected from a scientific point of view. Although the authors indicate that they carry out a review of the literature, this is not achieved adequately, since a systematic review methodology specific to this goal is not observed. On the other hand, the article in my opinion provides an adequate summary for people who do not belong to the area but are familiar with some key concepts described in the paper. It is worth mentioning that I think it is a well-written and presented article, in general, with an easy-to-understand structure. Furthermore, another criticism I would make is that although the ideas of CMMI and agile development seem well described to me, the same is not true regarding adequately justifying their specific application in SMEs. I think the article could be substantially improved. One suggestion I would make for this would be to present a case that gives strength to the central argument of the article, that is, CMMI and agile development are compatible and especially useful for SMEs. In this way, less emphasis could be given to the review (which seems insufficient to me in that sense) and the practical relevance of the argument would be raised. If so, the article could have an interesting projection. Abstract: The article seeks to analyze the existing collaboration networks between Information Systems (IS) researchers in Chile and Latin America. Co-authorship of research published in Contecsi and Infonor is used to carry out an analysis of social networks, explaining the latter. 3 questions are posed and answered later in the analysis of the results through tables and graphs; concluding several similarities between communities and that there is collaboration between IS researchers, which is unfortunately mostly intra-institutional. Evaluation: The work is well done. It presents a clear and concise structure that helps the reader understand the ideas being discussed. It is an interesting work that belongs to a process that has not yet ended due to the scarcity and continuity of data. The first caused by problems with registration and standardization of published papers, and the second because there will be new versions of the conferences that will provide new data. Even so, some problems can be identified, these are: 1) There is no data-based argument given as to why these are the two congresses chosen, given that these congresses are small. 2) Being a work of small scope (with respect to the conferences used), the usefulness of the result is also small. Minor comment: There is an error in the page numbering.

The work presents clearly and with good arguments an analysis of the collaboration between different researchers and institutions. The contribution made is interesting, first as an identification of opportunities for improvement in joint work, and second, as an analysis of the local publication. It would be interesting to apply the same methodology to other conferences in the area, whether Chilean or Latin American, and see the results obtained.

Although it is true that the work is well structured and shows signs of an adequate methodology, the usefulness of the study carried out is not clear. The results obtained and presented are based on a very short study period, which removes confidence from the conclusions. There are some small editing and writing errors in the text. It is recommended to expand the input data set of the study.

I find it an interesting work, mainly for providing empirical evidence on co-creation techniques. Its content and structure are technically well presented. However, the work has relevant omissions to assess its scientific contribution. For example, it does not present statistical analysis of the data provided. It only exposes a distribution of the results without showing statistical significance. I also miss a section (or in the conclusions) about limitations to the validity of the experiment. I think it has several threats to validity that have not been addressed. To name a few: it is not explained if the assignment to the groups was random; the time of the sessions is different; learning in previous sessions, etc. Other suggestions: p. 1 Title I think the title is not appropriate. It does not represent the core of the work, which is an experiment. p. 4 Second column Errors in bullet format p. 4 Third bullet second column every TIME on page. 5 Last bullet first column parenthesis

The article is about collaboration in the creation of content through social networks. The article is well structured and with some writing details. The bibliography does not comply with the format required by the congress. Regarding the topic of the article, initially there was doubt about whether the article was relevant for the congress, since it was an experiment on the social behavior of individuals through social networks. Later, when reviewing the experiment, it can be seen that the relevance is from the perspective of computer engineering education. For this reason, I recommend that the summary be modified in the article, mentioning the scope of the experiment so that the reader, from the beginning, has greater knowledge about the article. Furthermore, for greater relevance to the congress, it is recommended to place greater emphasis on collaboration for the development of some tasks specific to the discipline, such as systems analysis and/or design. Finally, the article is innovative in the way of carrying out some tasks through social networks.

This article presents the results of an experiment where it is evident that co-creation techniques applied through social networks and using mobile devices can enhance the creativity of the participants. It is an interesting topic and one that I consider can be a contribution to the congress. The way the article is presented should be improved. Some observations and/or comments: - The first two paragraphs of the Introduction are almost the entire Summary. - On page 4, change “every time” to “every time”. - On page 5, Step 3, it does not close parentheses on two occasions. - I suggest enlarging Figure 2. - I consider it excessive to use one page for a single figure. - In Reference [11], correct “Conference on the, 2009” - Page number 3 is repeated three times. - After page 7, continue with page 3. - Reference [4] says “2004b”

The paper has sections Introduction, Theoretical Analysis, Results, and Conclusions. The paper is poorly structured. In the Theoretical Analysis section, basic concepts and methodological aspects are mixed. The Results section of a case study that is nowhere defined. Subsequently, an analysis in words of results is carried out on an experimental situation that is not described in detail to guarantee minimum experimental replicability. Finally, the Acknowledgments section is highly informal. The writing does not follow the usual canon of papers (writing in the third person), but is presented in the first person. The order and presentation of each section needs to be substantially improved. In summary, the paper suggests the idea that the implementation of safety instrumented systems is vital to improve the safety and quality of processes in the industry. However, no specific models, experiences, empirical results or other equivalent are proposed. There are no real reasons to propose the acceptance of this work.

The paper presents research focused on evaluating the impact of security instrumented systems on the processes to which they are applied. The number of references is poor, considering the nature of the research. The use of references in the introductory section is especially scarce. Also, the introduction does not make very clear the contribution of the research or the methodology used, both things should be part of this section in a concise way. The use of first person plural in writing should be avoided (e.g., 3rd paragraph of the "theoretical analysis" section). Place references inside the paragraph, not outside (e.g., paragraph "Security Measures", "... started. [7]", should be "... started [7].". This is repeated elsewhere of the document. Writing error in the first paragraph of the 3rd page. Inconsistent reference format (second paragraph in "Remaining risk accepted"). Also poor use of punctuation (First paragraph of the 4th page). Regarding the results, they are not clear. The research question is poorly or ambiguously posed. Based on this, it is impossible to understand the contribution or approach proposed. This, added to the scarce theoretical framework provided, does not justify the relevance of the research presented. The conclusions do not refer to any aspect of research or future work. The format of references should be reviewed. For all the reasons stated above, the work is not of sufficient quality to be accepted.

This article presents a "state of the art" in cooperative systems with multiple robots. From this perspective, it is a properly written popular article that, from the bibliography point of view, includes current references. It is complex to evaluate an article of this type for its contribution, although it would have been appropriate to provide some final by-product, such as a comparative table or some evaluation (application areas?) based on the research work.

The work presents a study of the state of the art regarding multi-robot cooperative robotics systems. The focus of the review is the control architecture present in those systems. The English abstract should be reviewed in its writing, especially the use of words, such as "giving"->"providing", "panoramic"->"general", etc. The introduction does not provide a major contribution to the structure of the document. There is a little talk about the research associated with the topic, but with very little use of references and the section ends abruptly without explaining the methodology or contributions of the work. The work provides a very unclear "problem statement" that does not provide greater relevance. Furthermore, in addition to identifying some approaches to the context, the work does not propose any solution, alternative, categorization, framework or contribution in general to the (unclear) problem presented. In summary, the work makes a relatively adequate compilation of information regarding multi-robot cooperative robotics systems, however, beyond that, no real contribution or relevance to the work is revealed from a scientific point of view. If these points were clearer, if the methodology were presented directly, and if a specific research product were presented, this work could be accepted, but in its current state it is not recommended.

It is a study of the state of the art of multi-robot distributed control. Unfortunately we are in the preliminary stage of the investigation, so its references are according to the progress. The problem is that the problem to be solved is not perceived specifically, if it expresses the future intention of a line of work, indicating open spaces for research. There is a lack of preparation of the work, mnemonics that are not previously defined are used. You should avoid writing in the first person. The references are appropriate, but with little analysis, which could make the work more interesting.

A very well written and interesting article. It would have been interesting to include the original algorithms and those proposed in a more rigorous way (step 1, step 2, etc.) as well as a statistical analysis of the quality of the responses of both. Cite figure 4 in the text. Improve the quality of figures 6 and 7. In some parts place equation (n), in others eq. (n) and in other equation eq. (n)... register for the first or the second. Also register the names of the authors in the bibliographic references, since some use initials, others use full names, and others use mixed names.

El trabajo presenta un metodo de detección de fracturas en imágenes de pozos.  El trabajo en general, es muy poco convincente por varias razones:  1.- Invierte MUCHO espacio en describir los fundamentos pero no comparar y/o discutir con el estado del arte. Existen MUCHOS métodos adaptivos de clasificación de imágenes, y el problema que se presenta no tiene nada diferente, salvo una aplicación diferente.  2.- No está clara la hipótesis, por lo que no se puede medir la contribución del trabajo.  3.- El metodo de detección que se describe solo define formulas matemáticas para la caracterización geométrica de las fracturas. Esto es un procedimiento bastante poco robusto y más aún, los resultados evaluando el metodo tampoco son convincentes en  métricas estándares utilizadas (accuracy, error,  ROC curve, etc).  4.- La metodología experimental es muy débil, tampoco compara el metodo con el estado del arte, ni usa métricas estándares para analizar la precision/exactitud del metodo.

This work shows the proposed procedure for the automatic detection of fractures in wells. The methodology looks novel and interesting. The article shows the methodology well and is well written, but at the end of the article a better presentation of the results in real wells is missing. The contribution of the article is not clear, first it indicates that it is automatic detection and in another part it indicates that it is the modification to the algorithm. The presentation of results in real wells must be improved and compared with what is desired and perhaps with results from applying other techniques.

The paper describes the current context of the use of available technologies to automatically control the dosage of macronutrients in soilless crop treatments. The work is relevant in its definition and development. However, the title induces an expectation that cannot be satisfied in the document. The paper offers a discussion on the state of the art in technology for the problem addressed, however, it does not offer a comparative framework, selection criteria, or suggestion on good practices. As a first approach to the research area it is pertinent, however, some more of your own work should be added to the paper.

The article carries out an interesting bibliographic study on AI technology applied in the field of fertigation and nutrient dosing for soilless crops. It does not establish or describe the design of a solution based on a case study, and only remains a preliminary study. Therefore the title “Design and Construction of an Automatic System….” It does not correspond, and it would have to be oriented towards what it describes, that is to say something like: “Analysis and study of automatic systems…” It is an interesting survey-type article but it contradicts the title and the introduction, the conclusions are also not in accordance To this type of work, they should be more ad-hoc with comparative variables.

The title of the work leads the reader to expect to find the design and implementation of an irrigation control system, however as the reading of the document goes deeper this seems increasingly distant, since the author tells us proposes a review of various results of work carried out by third parties in a kind of compilation of information regarding the topic, to finally propose from its point of view which of these results could be considered of interest depending on the type of crop. It is necessary to modify the name of the article since it leads to confusion for the reader, since at the end of reviewing the document the design and even less the construction of the irrigation system has not been obtained as a result, only alternatives have been obtained to consider depending on various factors. . Perhaps it is necessary to focus on a specific type of crop to carry out the design and implementation of the irrigation system in detail in order to carry out tests that validate the work carried out.

The article describes an interesting application of control of a physical device (for the case under study, a Lego Mindstorms mobile robot), through the processing of signals derived from facial and/or mental changes, coming from an Emotiv EEG helmet. , which performs a high-resolution electroencephalogram. However, despite the interest of the work presented, the article lacks the rigor that characterizes the methodological research process, there is no critical bibliographic discussion, there is no clear definition of the problem to be investigated, it presents a poor discussion of results and abundant errors of form (e.g. page 3 presents the following text “Error! The origin of the reference cannot be found”, there is no page 2, etc.), which denote that the author was not rigorous in his review before sending . Finally, in my opinion, the work is a good contribution as an excellent project or workshop work within the curricular framework of a Computer Science or Electronics degree.
The paper corresponds to a very good application of a platform for gestural interface of actions with a robot. It is well written and with good use of references.

The document offers a comparison regarding the application of algorithms for the elimination of impulse noises on two types of hardware architectures: GPU and CPU. The document in general has poor writing, especially from page 4 onwards. The summary of the work is adequate, however its wording must be revised, e.g. the use of commas. In the introduction we start by talking about (i) image processing, in the middle (ii) we point out what is done in this work and then continue with (iii) a comparison between GPU and CPU. This structure is not suitable, it should be i-iii-ii, or just move iii to later sections and leave i-ii. In addition to that, not much is said about the experimental design and the results obtained, things that should be included in the introduction. Page 3 has a large blank space that needs to be fixed. Section "A. Review Phase" does not have much value as an independent section, since it mentions something that is natural in a study of this type, which is the literature review. It would look much better to join it with the next section (B). The section "D. Artifacts resulting from the project" talks about "research results", but only aspects of the built software are mentioned plus a results sheet, however results directly associated with the research are not observed. Page 5 has another blank space. In general, the presentation of results is poor. There is no table clearly indicating the results and the graphs presented do not look good. The analysis of the results is adequate but it lacks depth and relevance regarding what exactly we want to compare in both architectures. Images are not used or explained in the comparison. In summary, the work has a good destiny but requires in-depth corrective work to be adequate and scientifically acceptable.

In practice, it carries out communication using a distribution scheme of undeclared processes and data, to solve the noise problem, it does not indicate the image processing method, nor the strategy used, it manages information as an introduction to the CPU-GPU topic. Clearly it is a work that attacks a simple, preliminary image processing, where the method to be paralyzed and the strategy to be used for parallelization on GPU or CPU-GPU must be shown. From the point of view of image processing it is an unoriginal topic, but it is interesting that work on parallelism in CPU-GPU's begins, which is not new, but what is interesting are the parallelization strategies, how to partition the processes and data, how to use grids, blocks and threads, how to build a topology if possible, to provide a solution that minimizes execution time. Clearly specify what an image processing job is, filters used, parallelization method and strategy.

What is the contribution of work? The discussion of experiments and results is not very exhaustive. What is the working hypothesis? The objective to be compared is not clear since there is confusion between measuring aspects of "efficiency" (e.g. time) versus "effectiveness" (noise management and results obtained when processing images). The work organization is a bit confusing. In many places, the work is more focused on describing "systems" and the "application" rather than the contribution and the model itself. What is the proposed algorithm compared to?

This work describes in a practical way, a communication on how to introduce yourself to the use of a particular robot, under a free test environment, that works with this type of application. Although it is well written, it only serves as a tutorial, rather than the result of research. It is evident that work is being done very well, but it is preliminary work. The writing must be reviewed, because the summary is very introductory, not indicating the relevance of what the work presents, mnemonics are also used, which are not described before. Mnemonics that are not described in the text above are used in the summary and keywords. It has the peculiarity that it is a good job, but it is preliminary. It does not present the architecture of what was done, images that show the simulations, results achieved.

The work describes the navigation of a mobile robot using ROS and Raspberry PI hardware. The description tends to focus on configuration details, to the point of seeming like an installation or start-up manual. There is no report of results, much less analysis of the proposed solution. Given the above, and as presented, it is not an article for a conference. Just a report on how to use and configure the Raspberry PI.
Very interesting work as it incorporates an evaluation with users of the proposed prototype. It is well written and the results are clear.

The authors present the work of the construction and evaluation of a visual tool to help the data mining process. The results of using it on a group of users and on a specific task are shown. Suggestions: - The conclusions mention the opportunity to build other support tools, however, what they could be is not mentioned. - The reason for selecting WEKA as the base tool for building the proposed software is not mentioned. - The details of the experiment carried out should be added as an annex, indicating the model used, results obtained, etc. Form: - The second paragraph of the introduction does not make clear what its intention is, it should be redrafted. - Extensive use of acronyms is made, which confuses and makes reading the work difficult.

The article proposes and evaluates an application developed to better represent the results of association rule algorithms. In general, I find the article well written and structured. Perhaps, to improve the structure of the document, I would add a special section dedicated to the methodology and describe this in more detail. The authors qualitatively evaluate the performance of the interface in terms of the ease of interpretation of the information it provides. To do this, they expose the information to a group of users. The user evaluation method is a known and validated one. However, the article very superficially explains the user validation process used. On the other hand, the evaluation results presented are only descriptive. Statistical techniques for measuring interpreter consensus such as the Kappa index or others could have been used to analyze the quality of agreement between evaluators. In summary, I think it is a good article with a well-developed idea but that methodologically should be improved.

The article seeks to summarize and review the filtering and segmentation algorithms for point clouds in computer vision. In the words of the authors "The objective of this work is to carry out a review of the state of the art regarding the treatment of point clouds." In my opinion it does not achieve this objective stated by them. My reasons are expressed below. First, it is striking that as an article that seeks to establish the state of the art, it has a very scarce bibliography (14 articles). In that sense, it would be more appropriate to indicate that this work is preliminary (if it were so) since in this way such a low number of articles reviewed would be justified. Second, and which seems more relevant to me, the work does not make an adequate summary of the bibliography, but rather seems to be a note on some filtering and segmentation methods. A state-of-the-art review, in my opinion, should have a purpose such as identifying major gaps in the literature or research opportunities. Third, although a literature review is, in essence, a summary, it must be systematic. That is, it must have a method that has to be specified. For example, what was the search equation used and what was the time range and selection criteria of the articles reviewed or which were eliminated and why. Finally, although it has nothing to do with the content or objective of the article, there are obvious formatting problems. For example, the entire conclusion section is centered rather than justified. In addition, there are writing problems that in some parts make it difficult to understand the text. For example, the first paragraph in the "Segmentation" subsection says "The process of generating a surface model from a cloud of points, segmentation that extracts edges and partitions from the 3D world, points play an important role in fitting The surfaces." There are also spelling errors such as writing "laser" and "laser" in different parts of the document. In summary, the article does not achieve its objective of being a review of the state of the art and, in addition, it has obvious formatting errors.

The applications lack associated references, since there are many articles related to surface reconstruction applications. Summary: The work shows a model to measure value and seek its traceability. Co-creation of value with the client is proposed as a method of creating value. In order to analyze the contribution of co-creation, the concept of traceability is introduced. It then explains a series of variables proposed to measure the co-created value under a conceptual model together with another model that allows the traceability of the different contributions through links. Finally, the results of the model in one case are briefly presented. Evaluation: Implementing types of co-creation is very important for organizations today. It is interesting how the article mixes co-creation with traceability and proposes ways to measure it, presenting new tools for the organization. Unfortunately, the article has major weaknesses: 1) The scope may not be appropriate for a conference like INFONOR. 2) The results are brief and weakly exemplified, which makes it difficult to understand the use of the model. 3) More examples could be used for ease of reading. 4) The format of the paper has problems. Some accentuation and editing errors are observed in some parts (e.g. Results Section, "the model was validated...") A formatting problem is observed in the references. Some of the bibliographical references are very old.

The article is a mere announcement of the research work that will be carried out at a later stage. It barely shows the summary of the theoretical framework, with only some references and an insufficient study of the state of the art on the topic in question. Consequently there are no results on the basis of which to establish judgments. The title of the article is not related to what is presented in the body of the report. It presents a large number of writing, spelling and grammatical errors, illegible figures, references to non-existent figures, title of a table in another column, etc.

The work presents an ongoing investigation related to the cost of contracting IT services for organizations, specifically a case study is proposed in the Chilean Mining Industry. The work is focused on a business case, however, although the document emphasizes the theoretical compilation of the concepts associated with the financial and cost aspects of contracted IT services, the case study is not clear and the article seems incomplete. The structure of the document generates confusion because in the introduction objectives associated with the case study are established but at the end of the document the results are not presented because the research is in progress. It is suggested to limit the article and structure it better, in such a way that the preliminary results obtained can be presented up to the point at which the research project is, that is, a conceptual review of financial aspects for IT Services, without generating expectations against to the development of statistics or analysis of costs that have not yet been calculated. To have a strong emphasis on the review of concepts, the article has few references. It is recommended to improve the concepts and the conceptual base from a review of extensive literature that allows the research to be based and present partial results of the review of concepts. The work presents the design of AMADEUS, a platform that allows implementing mobile robot trajectories in semi-structured environments, for the investigation of the associated algorithms. The work in general is adequate, however it lacks something important: the comparison of the platform presented with other similar platforms. This is clearly reflected in the number of references. It would be appropriate to present references regarding other similar platforms, and indicate what the difference is between AMADEUS and them, which would clearly present the contribution of the work. Problems in writing the summary (To carry out the defined movements...). Also English must be revised. The quality of the equations used must be improved. The table on page 9 does not look good, this needs to be improved. Section 10 is called "results", however what it shows are case studies or application of the platform. In summary, the work is adequate to be accepted, however the state of the art regarding similar platforms must be improved.

The work presents us with an alternative platform that is feasible to be considered in robotics for educational purposes, given that depending on the level at which it is used, the study of the mobile can focus on some of the areas that are involved, such as instrumentation (sensors and actuators). ) or in programming (mobile navigation). Although the author does not refer in depth to the electronic aspect, it is evident that it is possible to also focus on the communication between the boards or on the motor control system, which in itself constitutes a problem of interest. In addition, the possibility of making improvements is raised, perhaps incorporating sensors of various types that allow more information to be captured from the environment. All this contributes to the Amadeus platform being considered a reference for robotics teaching and research. Both the development of the topic and the conclusions raised are consistent with what is presented in the summary of the article. Its use in undergraduate and postgraduate courses stands out, which strengthens its position as a didactic and research tool.

In general it is a well-written work, its content is easily understood, its presentation with the "copy paste" is helpful.

SUMMARY: The work presents and describes the application of a social network for news (4x4News), where the most relevant news will be present (among other characteristics). This application is characterized by a screen divided into a 16x16 matrix, where each cell is a news item. GENERAL EVALUATION: The work is well written and follows a format (almost) completely suitable for INFONOR. The application sounds interesting and potentially useful as an add-on for already commonly used social networks (e.g. Facebook). There are several independent points that I consider are important to resolve: 1) Although it is an interesting engineering work, I cannot see what the contribution is from a scientific point of view. What can be reused from this work for future work? scientist? 2) Since you offer an application, I think a link to (com)try this application is essential. 3) In my opinion, the website http://terra.cl is close to what is proposed by this work. This is so, because terra allows user registration (profiles), commenting on news, rating news, and configuring the website to display the news that a user wants. 4) This could be a minor detail, I think that the use of social networks could be used for something more than just showing the most important news (e.g. showing a kind of (social) tracking of a similar news item(s). ). MINOR DETAILS: - At the end of the introduction, the use of BOLD is not recommended. - “The headlines do not carry out a good analysis.” What is a “good” analysis? During the work, several adjectives are observed to be used in an ambiguous and unnecessary manner (e.g. “complex process” in section 2.1). - Within section 2: “Development”, there is the related work (section 2.1). This section should be restructured. - I think the citations like “X, et al., YEAR” (e.g. section 2.2 “Wilson, et al., 2014”) are incorrect. They should use “et al”. - Section 2.2, is the coincidence of words enough to say that two news items are similar? I think a deeper analysis is necessary. - Explain the concept “bundles” a little more. - Numbers [1] are used in the references, but numbers are not used in the text. I recommend following the INFONOR format.
