The article presents an application in the business field oriented to retail trade in the commercial company “Caracol” in Cuba. The theme of the work is fundamentally oriented to present and comment on the InfoCom application and how it eventually works in the company. However, in terms of its theoretical and methodological discussion and the analysis of the results, this article presents multiple shortcomings that are detailed below: The introduction of the article in general highlights the relevance of the application built for the company in particular but does not detail what is innovative of this proposal and why this information system is better in terms of development or what are the characteristics that distinguish it from what currently exists on the market. Nor does the author clearly establish the motivation that led him to develop a new solution for the problem posed. A research objective as such of the article is not defined since it is mentioned that this will be to “expose a commercial information system adaptable to any retail business…….” . In general, we want to present the built application and do not specify what is expected from the article, the methodologies to be used and what is innovative in terms of development for the discipline of information systems. One of the main limitations of this article is the state of the art. The literature review is almost non-existent in relation to the theories that support the development of the application and the main authors on platform development issues of this nature are not mentioned. No theoretical framework is established in the article in terms of design or implementation of the application. Nor are any proposals discussed in these terms, so it is possible to say that there are no theoretical references in terms of analysis, design and implementation. This difficulty means that the evaluation of what has been developed is only based on general opinions of what the concept of information systems is. The research methodology is another important shortcoming of this article. The article moves between the importance of the application to a description of what is possible to do with it without establishing clear and accepted development and implementation methodologies (neither for the design of the tool or for the analysis of the results obtained from its use. ). This complicates the evaluation of the work since there are no research questions to answer, nor ways to evaluate whether the author's expectations are met or if the results obtained will be valid. The author of the article should present and describe the research designs to be used to allow their validity to be evaluated. Most of the article is in the development item and it defines and details the characteristics of the company in which the study will be developed. It is not clearly specified which parts of the systems are acquired commercially and which are developed internally and how the connection with other existing platforms is achieved. Nor are any process or data models associated with this construction established. The authors limit themselves to explaining the functionalities of the tool and how it will be used in the company, but it is not possible to know how it was implemented and compare the results that stand out as relevant to the implementation. Although the tool may be very simple from a design and architecture point of view, a description that presents process models using ad-hoc tools and at least a description of the design stage would be expected. The results obtained are generally mentioned as something that was achieved and as percentages of improvements in management and it is not possible to draw valid conclusions about them. The conclusion of the article is weak in terms of the results obtained from the design and implementation of the application and above all the contribution of the study to the discipline of information systems. I consider that the article requires major changes and that work must be done on defining the objective, the methodology to be used for the analysis and design of the platform. Therefore I suggest on this occasion your rejection for this conference

The article presents a commercial information system adaptable to any retail business by facilitating the work of data consolidation and completing the automation of the import, distribution and supply process. Despite good presentation and language, it is not a work that presents research results. Rather, it is the summary of the development of a system of medium complexity. Nor does it expose lessons learned or practices that could contribute to other developers. In conclusion, its novelty and contribution to science is limited. Under these conditions, I think it cannot be accepted for the research track.

This work is part of the area of ​​business architecture and proposes an interesting business rule automation model to improve the flexibility of information systems applied to financial entities. The proposed model is aimed at decoupling the business logic from the business rules. The problem addressed in the article is adequately supported by the difficulties mentioned in the field of software projects and in the financial world. The author could go a little deeper into project development experiences in other areas and the relevance of business rules in the development of efficient information systems in the company. The objective declared by the author is to propose a methodology that makes the operation of information systems in financial entities more flexible, which is generally adequately explained. The bibliographic review is relevant to the topics addressed and the theories and models considered are appropriate to the objective that has been set. The analyzes associated with the concept of business rules and system architecture are relevant to the topic. The author should specify how the relationship between process modeling and the design and characterization of business rules is established. It is mentioned that they use decision point tables, but these are not mentioned in detail or visually. The author should better support the choice of “Pipes and Filter” as a system architecture model. It would also be important to highlight whether there are similar works carried out in other areas (since the author does not mention it). The methodological aspect of the work focuses on describing the process through which the definition of the software architecture is reached to automate the rules. of business and the tools that were used in its development. This methodological approach is appropriate and clearly associated with a case study application. The important contribution in this aspect is the detailed description of the process from the creation of the rules to the design and development of the proposed application architecture. The author should make a summary table that represents this process in summary form. It is clear that the results of this work have the desired validity, since it is based on the use of models and tools already validated in the field of rule-based business platform design. The contribution of the work is important since it systematizes a process that is widely used in the development of information systems that are flexible and adaptable to the changing environment. However, these contributions are not clearly reflected in the conclusions, which is why the authors are suggested to improve the conclusions by including significant contributions in methodological terms and contributions to the discipline in which the article is framed. The formal aspects of the work are satisfactory to the congress. There are minor details in the grammar such as the letter U missing in the first paragraph of the introduction. It is suggested to accept the article with minor modifications

Throughout the article the role of test automation within software testing and more generally in the assurance framework is exaggerated. A maturity model for software testing necessarily includes more aspects than automation. Automated cases will always coexist with manual cases and evaluations carried out by people. As discussed in the article, automation is a very general concept, it can encompass generation, execution, evaluation (for example: mutation, coverage criteria) and validation (oracle problem). Although the motivation is clearly expressed in the introduction, references are needed to substantiate the statements made about the role of testing and the impact of automation on it. Saying that automation allows testing to be done faster or at a lower cost is simplistic: this depends on the context. The costs of generating automatic test cases, the estimate on the future evaluation of the software and the expiration of the test cases, along with other factors, must be taken into account in the cost model to determine the desirability of automating a certain part of the proof. The section dedicated to software testing makes general definitions and traces the history of testing since mainframes. For a research article, I suggest making more specific definitions related to the focus of the study (experimental studies on testing techniques, automation, testing costs, maturity models). It would be appropriate to put the development of the maturity model after presenting the related work. The process to obtain the proposal of a maturity model for testing is not described. The development of the model must be linked to other existing maturity models (for example the Testing Maturity Model), connections must be established with accepted testing literature or standards (for example ISO 29119) and in general with software process models. The search string used is not made explicit. Not all models found should be classified as 'maturity models'. Some of the models included are clearly more general models, which do not focus on the problem of test automation. These differences should at least be discussed. The attributes used in Table III are not explained, nor the way to obtain the maturity level results. What does 'level of published opinions' mean? This concept is ambiguous. The description of this research process must be reinforced since it is key to obtaining the 'adolescent' level result.

The work is titled "Current Maturity of Software Testing Automation Development." The document shows a series of sections that report on work carried out in terms of literature review and some approaches to a proposal to restructure a scale of particular maturity levels for the test automation process. However, the work lacks a logical structure that allows determining whether its main contribution or objective is in the review of literature or in the proposal of new levels of maturity for the testing process. It is recommended to do a complete review of the information presented and possibly restructure the document presented. The report of this review was divided into sections, in order to provide suggestions that allow the work to be improved. Section -Systematic review It is important that the authors review the fact of using a systematic review method that is not yet published, there being several published, tested and recognized methods for Software engineering. They should justify the selection of the method proposed by Serna M. identified with the number [16] in the work. It is essential to explain the validation that is carried out with respect to the peer review of the articles, since it is not clear how a peer review of the published articles can be accessed in order to validate them and how a validation process is carried out from of said information, taking into account the number of revisions that would have to be made for each article found (978). Test automation Although, the work reports a proposed model to evaluate the maturity of the software test automation process. The model as such is not described. The article is limited to presenting a reference scale associated with the maturity of a human being. Therefore, it is essential that the article indicates several aspects to consider the structuring and definition of a model. Among the most important aspects to consider are: 1. A scientific and formal justification on which the authors of the work are based to propose the maturity model and the selection of the maturity levels of a human being as a point of comparison with a possible level of maturity of the test automation process. 2. Formal justification of why not use the CMMI model and the maturity level structure proposed in it to evaluate the test automation process. The above, taking into account that the maturity model defines an appropriate maturity scale to evaluate processes in software engineering. That is, why is it necessary to rethink these maturity levels for the test automation process and propose a new scale based on the maturity of a human being? 3. At the research level, how are the maturity levels characterized in terms of test automation? Although the article characterizes each level, indicating the possible characteristics of the test automation process, it does not indicate how said characterization was determined, nor is a related formal and scientific justification shown. Related work The work presents a systematic review, under which it is possible to identify work related to the area of ​​study, in this case test automation or maturity levels for test automation. However, the authors present the systematic review separately from the related work section, when it seems that the studies selected as related work should be part of the analysis of the results of the systematic review. Furthermore, the systematic review makes it possible to determine research gaps or niches (research opportunities) to determine an area of ​​work with a specific problem and, from there, propose a possible solution to said problem. In this case, the article presents the systematic review as additional work and subsequent to the proposal of maturity levels for the test automation process. Likewise, the authors show the selection of some related works, it is understood that they are related to test automation, however the first Michael Grottke, indicate precisely that he does not focus on the topic to be discussed in the work they present but on a statistical proposal for test automation. Therefore it would not enter as a related work. Maturity of software test automation development To make a comparison of the test automation process and maturity levels, the authors present Table 3. It indicates that the first column contains the traditional stages of a testing process. It is necessary to indicate under which methodology these stages are selected as traditional or to have a reference as a justification for the selection of these and not other stages. In this section there is no clear explanation of the determination of the maturity levels in each stage. It is essential to have described the research analysis carried out that results in the definition of the maturity level of each of the stages of the testing process. The table is not sufficient explanation for the analysis, as it only reports the results. At this point, if what you are looking for is to propose a new maturity scale for the testing or test automation process, it is most convenient to validate said proposed scale with a case study. In this work, although the authors show a table where they seem to determine that the maturity level is "adolescent", it is not possible to understand in what context the test automation process is being evaluated. At least one case should be contextualized, indicating: region, time, type of projects or companies and methodology used to evaluate the test automation process. The above is the basis to justify that in a certain context the test automation process is at X level of maturity (of the proposed scale). Also arguing the criteria that were taken into account to assign said level of maturity.

The model used to measure the quality of data on the web is chosen without justification through an analysis that establishes its efficiency in comparison to other models. The review carried out on the concept of open data is minimal and is not present in the review carried out as this topic has been addressed in different countries and the results they have obtained. The authors should further elaborate on the concept of open data at the government level for transparency and public interest and better support this division in the literature. The methodological aspect of the work focuses on using the 5-star model and describing a general classification that is made based on this model. Although this methodological approach is appropriate and is clearly associated with the topic, it does not present propositions to be evaluated (research questions or hypotheses to be tested). The diagnosis is basic and general based on four variables that allow each platform to be classified. The author should also establish a categorization of what the study subjects are (the Chilean government is mentioned but there are only four platforms out of the total platforms owned by the government). In this sense, it should refer to transversal central service platforms (since it does not analyze local governments at any time). This work is based on the use of a diagnostic model already validated in the literature; however, its application is limited and in my opinion it does not allow generalize to the government as a whole. The contribution of the work is important since it presents relevant information in the process of arriving at what open government is. However, the generalization of their results is questionable since it is limited to four variables and four websites.

The latter is the greatest weakness of the work. In reference to the form: there are many spelling and writing errors, the length of some paragraphs is excessive and the writing of some topics that should be summarized, it also writes in the fourth person and in some parts in the future tense, the writing should be standardized to the 3rd person and present tense, except in conclusions that may occupy past tense. It is an article that can be accepted but requires a profound re-ordering in terms of form, and fundamentally in relation to the data mining model, its analysis and exhaustive evaluation, as well as its results.
